Politicians are hesitant to focus on defence, and manifestos from major parties lack detail on the subject. Despite a more dangerous and unstable world, the UK, like other European nations, has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, reducing army size and naval and air fleets.  UK defence spending has fallen to sixth place globally and is likely to drop below the NATO 2% GDP target, with only smaller parties committed to meeting it.  While further defence cuts are anticipated, some parties are limiting their options due to commitments like Trident replacement.  There is no political consensus on the nuclear deterrent, and its future is uncertain.  The UK is acquiring new aircraft carriers, but there are concerns about manning levels and equipment, raising fears of a "hollow force" and making it harder for the UK to maintain its global military influence.

Barcelona insists they have not committed any offence regarding the signing of Neymar for Â£48.6m, of which Neymar's parents received Â£34m. The total cost of Neymar is estimated to be Â£106.8m.  Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president and is being investigated for misappropriating money.  There are allegations that the actual cost of Neymar was greater than initially stated, leading to ongoing investigations. Barcelona made a tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend their reputation, while maintaining their original tax payment was correct. It is unconfirmed if this payment will stop the investigation.

Michael Luciw, aged 27, died in a car crash as a passenger in a van hit by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died and was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Following this, Mr Luciw's family stated that retired people should have regular driving tests, a view supported by Mr Harrington, the van driver who was injured in the crash. Age UK stated that it was vital for older people to drive for as long as possible.  Currently in the UK, drivers over 70 must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licence, with no medical or driving test required. The DVLA stated they have no plans to restrict licensing based on age as evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause accidents.

The safety of implants used to treat incontinence has been questioned by women due to side effects.  An independent expert, Alison Britton, will examine a report on these implants after concerns were raised about its conclusions, leading to resignations from the review group. The report recommends that these procedures should not be routine for pelvic organ prolapse, and instead, patients should be offered various treatments and information to make informed decisions.  Mandatory reporting of adverse events was also recommended.  Despite calls for a ban, these recommendations will be implemented, though the power to ban the procedures lies with a UK regulatory body, not the government. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologised for failing to unite the panel around the report, which has been controversial.  Two members of the review group resigned, expressing dismay at the report, and it was claimed that parts of the report were removed.  Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had these implants, and some have suffered complications, with over 400 women taking legal action.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record in the 5K at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned if the race met UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking, mentioning concerns about it being a "genuine race" and drug testing. British Athletics stated Muir's time is expected to be officially classified as a record. McColgan praised Muir's ability, suggesting she could run even faster and win world medals, comparing Muir's record-breaking race to her own from 25 years prior. McColgan is pleased that a fellow Scot broke her record and acknowledged Muir's world-class status and previous achievements, including breaking her own British 1500m record and reaching the Olympic final.
Jung won gold aboard Sam in an equestrian event at the Rio Olympics. Astier Nicolas of France won silver, and Phillip Dutton of America won bronze. William Fox-Pitt of GB finished 12th.

Murray, a Briton, won against Fognini, the 29th seed, in four sets: 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes and concluded at 20:57 BST. Murray secured his place in the last 16 for the 11th time and will next play Benoit Paire in the fourth round.  Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week. Murray described the match as tense and not his best tennis, mentioning the fading light and the possibility of the roof closing. He acknowledged he needs to improve his movement for his next match.

A sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST led to police finding people still at the bar and evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. As a result, the bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside of licensing hours. Ms O'Neill was fined Â£3,000 and Mr Thomas was fined Â£1,000. The judge highlighted Ms O'Neill's "appalling record" and the improper management of the bar.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist party manifesto with the slogan "Domination doesn't work, partnership does". The party wants the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive issue, but focus has shifted to comments made by Mr Nesbitt.  Mr Nesbitt stated he would prefer to go into Stormont with the SDLP rather than Sinn FÃ©in and that he would not withdraw his comments. The manifesto, named 'Real Partnership', includes action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community and guaranteeing no group is worse off due to Brexit.  Mr Nesbitt believes the election is about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption".

A motion confirmed by Justice Minister Claire Sugden will go to the assembly for approval. This motion aims to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, regarding pardons for abolished sexual offences, similar to 'Turing's Law'.  The motion is expected to contain provisions for both posthumous pardons and for living gay and bisexual men.  The Minister secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass this motion to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland compared to England and Wales and to right the wrongs of the past. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second to Faith Kipyegon in a race with a time of four minutes, 19.12 seconds. This time broke Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list. Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio. This was her first 1500m race of the season, and she is balancing training with her veterinary studies.
This passage contains pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that are ranked as "most excellent" for water quality.

This passage states that barrister Richard Horwell QC believes the Russian state was likely behind the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006, as suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive.  Litvinenko died after drinking tea containing polonium-210 with the suspects, who deny wrongdoing.  The presence of polonium suggests Russian state involvement, though direct orders from Vladimir Putin are not confirmed.  Motives could include Litvinenko's defection to the UK and criticism of Putin.  The suspects left a polonium trail, extradition attempts failed, and they remain in Russia.  The risk to the public from polonium exposure is unknown, and Litvinenko was poisoned twice.

Following the retirement of Michael Clarke, Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as captain. David Warner, aged 28, has been named as vice-captain. Smith's appointment is for an ongoing basis and he will captain the one-day and Twenty20 teams, in addition to the Test team. Smith previously captained in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured. Warner's appointment as vice-captain comes despite past disciplinary issues, with selectors believing he has matured. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the Ashes Test starting on 20 August.

Mr. Farron refused to answer if homosexual sex was a sin. He stated he was passionate about LGBT-plus rights and defending equal marriage would be a top agenda. He also wanted to extend marital rights to transgender people.  When questioned about voting against the Equality Bill in 2007, he stated he supported equality and that the Lib Dems had concerns about the bill regarding "protection of individual liberties".

Sanofi, a French company, closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use this plant for pharmaceutical production and hopes to employ former Sanofi staff. Accord believes this investment will positively impact the area. Councillor Nick Forbes of Newcastle City Council views this as "fantastic news" for Newcastle and the North East, strengthening its science and healthcare sector reputation. He highlights Accord as a global pharmaceutical company whose investment and skilled jobs will boost the local economy. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries globally.

Richard Ellis is leaving his role at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. These departures, according to Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, suggest the council struggles to retain senior staff, and he anticipates further departures. Richard Ellis was the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Mr Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Mr Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked all three for their "dedication and professionalism".

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has had mechanical issues.  Martin initially stated he was quitting road racing but clarified he is not quitting racing or road racing, but has no plans to road race on Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster and felt like a test rider. He believes the bike is not competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix and the team withdrew him from the event. Martin wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 governorship posts, while the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) won 8. This is the biggest defeat for the PDP since 1999, and follows their loss in the presidential poll last month. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State. The APC gained historic wins, especially in the north and Lagos, but did not win any oil-producing states. Elections were marred by violence in some areas, and the APC retained power in Lagos state. The PDP, in power for 16 years, is seen to be in decline due to voter desire for change, defections, corruption allegations, and failure to end the insurgency in the north-east.

Mighty, a US environmental group, has made claims against the agricultural commodities trader Olam, and its main stakeholder Temasek, accusing them of unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to haze. Both companies reject these allegations. Mighty's report suggests Olam and Temasek could be encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices and that Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies". Olam's CEO states the firm has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and is vetting suppliers, and Temasek dismisses the allegations, supporting no-burn policies. Mighty also raises concerns about Olam's practices in Gabon, accusing them of rainforest destruction, which Olam denies, stating its operations are responsible and transparent.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters on 27 August 2016 after a new law was introduced. This law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury, having only been fit enough for the bench in the last two games. David Nugent could return from a groin injury. Jacob Butterfield hopes to be recalled to the team.

The telecoms regulator in Pakistan lifted the ban on YouTube because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. YouTube denies that authorities can filter content. Some activists are requesting transparency regarding the agreement between Google and the government, even though many young Pakistanis are happy about the ban being lifted. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed internet service providers to allow access to YouTube. Google has provided a process for the PTA to request blocking access to offending material, which Google/YouTube will restrict for users in Pakistan. However, YouTube stated that government requests for content removal are not automatically granted and are subject to community guidelines and local laws, and these requests will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report. The ban was initially imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 due to the film 'Innocence of Muslims'.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is being asked to withdraw from his position by LFA boss Musa Bility due to a potential conflict of interest. This is because Scala shares nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility refers to Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations and threatens to go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw.  Scala's spokesman argues there is no conflict of interest as there is no incumbent president in this election, unlike in 2015 when Scala withdrew due to sharing nationality with Sepp Blatter. The election to replace Blatter will take place in 18 days.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died at Harford Attachments in Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were working in a paint-spraying area.  A flashover explosion, caused by toxic fumes and ignition, is suspected to be the cause of their deaths.  Forensic inquiries, witness statements, and an investigation by the Health and Safety Executive are underway.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for lodging complaints against Caf during this year's Nations Cup, but avoided this by apologising. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup after being replaced as 2015 hosts due to Ebola concerns, but this ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both nations are now participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw.

Chelsea won against City 3-1 at Etihad Stadium.  A mass fracas occurred in the 95th minute resulting in City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho being sent off.  Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct after a challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, and Fernandinho received a three-match ban for clashing with Fabregas. City manager Pep Guardiola apologised for his team's part in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. This victory is England's second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his performance, including scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, as well as taking wickets and catches.  England's captain, Alastair Cook, also scored centuries in the match.  Pakistan was bowled out for 198 and 234 in their innings.  Commentators praised England's performance and highlighted Pakistan's batting struggles and lack of confidence.  Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment and hoped his team would work hard to improve. The third Test will be at Edgbaston starting on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is head coach for the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and Rob Howley is part of his backroom team. McBryde will be head coach for Wales for the third time on summer tours. The WRU will appoint assistant coaches to support McBryde for the summer tour. The WRU believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team and that the tour of New Zealand will be a test for coaches.

Southampton took the lead in the match against Hull City with a penalty in the sixth minute from Charlie Austin. Hull City faced further setbacks losing two starting strikers to injury in the first half. However, Hull City turned the game around in the second half with goals from Snodgrass and Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull City's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made several saves and Clucas cleared a ball off the goalline, securing a 2-1 victory for Hull. This win marked Hull's first league win since August 20th and ended their six-game losing streak. Snodgrass's return from injury and performance were highlighted as crucial for Hull's victory, while Southampton's manager cited a lack of concentration after a European game as a factor in their loss.

A crash occurred at approximately 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The crash involved a motorcyclist, who died and lived locally, and a tractor driver, who was not injured. Lincolnshire Police are appealing for witnesses and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov in Macedonia cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims that were revealed by covert recordings. He stated this was to "put an end to the agony" before upcoming elections. This action was criticised by both the opposition and EU officials. The recordings, which have been released since 2015, have caused turmoil in Macedonia and allegedly show ministers plotting vote-rigging and a murder cover-up. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who has been releasing these recordings, accuses the government of corruption and wiretapping. The government denies these accusations and accuses Mr Zaev of trying to destabilise the nation.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth. Swansea are looking to quickly appoint a new boss, with Paul Clement as their first choice.  Swansea are concerned about potential relegation and the difficulty of returning to the Premier League from the Championship.  Swansea was promoted to the Premier League in 2011, after a period of financial difficulty in the past. Curtis believes Swansea has declined since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to frequent changes in management and that the 'Swansea Way' has been diluted. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and reminds new players of the club's history and the importance of avoiding relegation.

Dagenham lost to Orient, resulting in their relegation to the National League despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Orient's goals were scored by Jay Simpson and Armand Gnanduillet, keeping their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, managed by John Still, are returning to the National League after reaching League One in 2010 and the Football League in 2007. Dagenham have League Two's worst goal difference and have struggled in attack this season. Orient's interim manager Andy Hessenthaler mentioned the difficulty of recent managerial changes, while Dagenham's manager John Still cited lack of organisation and discipline as reasons for their defeat.

Former Reds captain Steven Gerrard, aged 36, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February. This will be his first job since retiring as a player.  Liverpool manager Klopp described this as "wonderful news" and mentioned Gerrard wants to be a manager in the future and is ready to learn. Klopp believes Gerrard has a bright future. Gerrard retired in November after a 19-year career and is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.
Morton won comfortably against Alloa in a match where McManus scored twice, Forbes and Johnstone also scored for Morton, and McAusland scored for Alloa.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham, which have since been closed. These closures are part of an investigation into 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. The Chief Inspector of Schools, Sir Michael Wilshaw, expressed shock at the conditions and concern that this is likely just the start of the problem, with children potentially at risk of abuse or radicalisation.  The government is considering further regulation of educational places and has funded a team to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups. The Education Secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare prosecution cases against unregistered schools, requiring her consent for any prosecution to proceed.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. It is produced by lead distiller Kate Macinnes, who is excited about the potential of the Scottish Borders becoming a region of distilling excellence. Lilliard Gin production is small scale and aims to capture the local flavour palette using wild food from the Teviot valley.  Born in the Borders sees the gin distillery as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery, highlighting Lilliard Gin's use of local botanicals. The gin is named after Lilliard, a heroine from the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545, reflecting the landscape and the female production team.

Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds in August 2013. Gary Green was over two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer.  Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure safety, prosecuted under health and safety law as the incident occurred on private land. The incident happened at approximately 09:15 on 9 August and involved a tractor. Harry's mother stated the family is changed forever and hopes to remember the good times with Harry.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguay striker, is now permitted to train and participate in friendly matches for his new club Barcelona, with his first training session scheduled for Friday and public presentation on Monday.  The ruling by Cas still prevents him from playing in organised matches, but allows participation in all football-related activities.  He remains suspended for eight international games and his competitive Barcelona debut is expected in October against Real Madrid.  This Cas ruling comes after an appeal against Fifa's ban for biting Giorgio Chiellini, with Cas deeming the initial "all football activity" ban as excessive, although generally confirming Fifa's sanctions.  While Suarez can now train, play friendlies, attend matches and participate in promotional activities, reactions to the ruling are mixed, with some considering the sanctions still disproportionate, especially given Suarez's history of disciplinary issues.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas from Lithuania and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene on 18 March 2014.  The race was a 380-metre course with haystacks, a steep slope and water pistols as obstacles.  Competitors did not need to be married and included various combinations such as men carrying women, men carrying men and a woman carrying a woman. Richard and Anna trained for a week and will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

Car tax discs are being scrapped in October and replaced with an electronic system, allowing payment by monthly direct debit. Concerns were raised about job losses at the DVLA due to this change. Minister Stephen Hammond responded to concerns, stating job roles will change, and any staff reductions will be managed through redeployment. While noting job opportunities will reduce, Mike Hedges welcomed the minister's assurances of redeployment over redundancies.

Hungary believes the EU should not interfere with "domestic issues" and has backing from Poland to veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. The EU objects to Hungary's controls on asylum seekers and NGOs, as well as a higher education law that critics say could close the Central European University. Hungary states it will not backtrack on these issues, considering them "national competence". Poland will veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU is putting pressure on Hungary to withdraw these laws, with warnings of action if there are no positive developments. Hungary is housing asylum seekers in shipping containers and the Higher Education Law could force the closure of the Central European University. A draft NGO law is expected to go before parliament.

A film starring Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. A star will play Mrs Potts. Bill Condon is the director and filming will begin in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times, has died. He was diagnosed with cancer, which he described as "the full English".  Gill's final column will be published in the Sunday Times tomorrow.  Martin Ivens, the Sunday Times editor, described Gill as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper. Gill was known for his "incomparable" wit, "dazzling and fearless" writing, and intelligence. He was a controversial writer, known for causing outrage with some of his articles.  Gill was born in Edinburgh in 1954, overcame dyslexia, and had a long writing career starting with art reviews and then moving to Tatler and the Sunday Times. He was married twice and engaged to his partner Nicola Formby at the time of his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was attacked in Ulan Bator. Russian news reported he was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, but the Russian embassy stated these reports were "distorted".  Mr Sukhbaatar's father said his son was in a coma for about 10 days after the beating and sustained serious brain injuries. The attack occurred because Mr Sukhbaatar was wearing a deel with a swastika, which is a traditional Mongolian symbol, not a hate symbol in Mongolia.  A Russian official is accused of the attack but has not been identified.  The Russian embassy claims reports of the assault are "distorted".  The suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer and the case is under investigation, but the suspect was not detained because the injury was not considered serious, not due to diplomatic immunity.

Campaigners from action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday at the airport on the northern runway at 03:30 BST in opposition to the airport's expansion plans. These men and women have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and will appear in court on 19 August. Following the protest, the Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

Glamorgan played against Gloucestershire, in which Nick Selman scored 101 runs for Glamorgan. Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets for Gloucestershire, in cloudy conditions. Gloucestershire struggled in their innings and the day ended evenly balanced. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan because Jacques Rudolph has a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee revealed he was planning to make a false report to police to ambush and shoot officers at the Dee Estuary. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court on Friday and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made on two occasions late at night while Hughes was drunk. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for other firearms offences at the time, for which he was later cleared.

Surrey played Yorkshire. Yorkshire reduced Surrey to 8-2, but Surrey recovered to score 255-7, with Davies and Foakes sharing a 130 run stand. Yorkshire were all out for 236, with Meaker taking three wickets. Bresnan scored 68 for Yorkshire. Surrey won the match.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST because a pump could not manage incoming water.  The RNLI lifeboat crew used a pump and towed the trawler to Holyhead.

Muir told BBC Scotland that she will not participate in the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships and achieved a personal best in the 5,000m. She is returning to university to complete her final year but is considering participating in the World Indoor Championships in March.

This passage is a column by Robbie Savage discussing Liverpool's current football season compared to the previous one.  Liverpool are not performing at the level required to challenge for the title this season, unlike last season when they were title contenders.  Several factors contribute to this, including the loss of key goal scorers Suarez and Sturridge, unsuccessful striker signings, a drop in work rate and intensity, and ongoing defensive issues despite spending on defenders.  Savage predicts Liverpool will struggle against Chelsea in their upcoming match and suggests a lineup for Liverpool.  The passage also touches on Steven Gerrard's future at Liverpool and the physical and mental challenges he faces.

A ÃÂ£45m facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock. It will contain primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council will seek permission to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a writer born and educated in Kilmarnock, who was passionate about education. McIlvanney was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" and wrote novels such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty and The Big Man. He was also a poet, journalist and broadcaster.

An area of Gourock near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon. This was due to a sea mine, thought to be British and from the 1940s or 1950s, which had been spotted on Monday.  Residents close to the area were advised to take safety precautions. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice given to those within 500m of the device.  Exclusion zones were in place on the river and at sea, causing ferry service disruption.  Authorities stated the evacuation was a precaution and there was no immediate danger.  Due to the deteriorated state of the mine and the unknown quantity of explosives it contained, it was moved to a safer location. Inverclyde Council thanked residents for their patience during the evacuation.

The funding for several sports has been cut for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, cycling and badminton. Cycling's funding was cut by more than Â£4m, and badminton's funding removal is considered "incomprehensible" despite them winning a bronze medal at Rio.  A total of Â£345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is less than the funding for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set medal targets for Tokyo, aiming for 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. While badminton's funding was removed, Judo, which also won a bronze medal, received a slight funding increase. UK Sport defends the funding decisions as necessary to prioritize medal potential. Team sports like basketball, handball, and volleyball have also had funding issues and are critical of UK Sport's approach to team sports development. Funding for new Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in East Cliff, Bournemouth, will be demolished to build a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. Councillors approved the development, stating it would help tourism and improve living for older people, despite objections from English Heritage who felt the scale would harm the conservation area. The new development, proposed by The East Cliff Project LLP, will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. While there were 246 letters of support, 49 residents, the Ancient Monuments Society, and English Heritage objected to the demolition due to the loss of historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked and killed in Brecon by Jake Vallely. The attack occurred outside a bar called The Cellar in the early hours of 8 May while Pte Boyd was off-duty and in Brecon for training exercises. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as the court was told he was not present during the attack. The police described the attack as a "despicable act" and Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him, highlighting the impact of his loss.

Following an error where voters were turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list, Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet Council by "mutual agreement".  An independent investigation has been launched by the council, and Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over.  Barnet Council apologised for the issues and offered emergency proxy votes. Mr Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the problems. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and will examine the arrangements for the EU Referendum in June.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored for Gateshead with a free-kick, and Sean Newton scored for Wrexham with a set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, said that beating Wrexham showed that Gateshead is a decent side and that their second goal was great. Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment, stating that their second half was not as good as their first half.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries. Norway is ranked as the best country, while Afghanistan is the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb is creating a network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially over 2,000, to deliver global broadband, particularly for schools. This project requires a shift in satellite manufacturing towards high volume and low cost, using assembly line methods similar to car and plane production. Airbus and OneWeb have established assembly lines in France and Florida, employing automation and a scaled supply chain. The first satellites are scheduled to launch in April next year, with a rapid launch cadence to follow, aiming for nearly 300 satellites by end of 2020/early 2021, and over 600 a year later. While other companies are also planning mega-constellations, OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage. Debris mitigation is a key consideration, with OneWeb committing to de-orbit satellites within two years and implementing measures for reliable de-orbiting. This new manufacturing approach may not be suitable for all types of satellites, particularly those for specialised missions.

The UK government's recent spending review has placed pressure on public expenditure in Scotland, according to Mr. Swinney.  The UK government states that Scottish ministers will have Â£390m more to spend next year.  Mr. Swinney is scheduled to present his spending plans on Wednesday. The Scottish government argues that UK government cuts since 2010 mean their discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower by 2019-20 than in 2010-11. Mr. Swinney states that the UK government has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year until 2020.  He also said Scotland will protect key priorities like schools, hospitals and police. The UK government responded that the Scottish government will have Â£390m more to spend next year, rising to Â£750m if underspend is included, and that the block grant will be almost Â£30bn. Labour's public services spokeswoman Jackie Baillie said it is time for Mr. Swinney to back up his anti-austerity stance with real action and that Scotland needs a long-term budget.

People with severe disabilities and their carers face challenges when leaving the house due to a lack of suitable toilet facilities, specifically 'Changing Places' toilets.  These enhanced facilities are different from standard accessible toilets and are needed by people who require more space and equipment like hoists and benches.  Currently, recommendations exist to install Changing Places in larger buildings, but campaigners are advocating for these to be compulsory in building regulations.  The lack of these facilities leads to stress, isolation, and feelings of being undervalued by society for those affected. While there are logistical and financial barriers to installing Changing Places, especially in existing buildings, making them compulsory in new larger complexes is being pushed as a solution, with examples like Arsenal Football Club showing the positive impact of installing these facilities.

A group of Italian consumer organisations has made a formal complaint to the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's denies this, stating they share risks and rewards with franchisees. The complaint is supported by the Service Employees International Union and European unions who believe McDonald's abuses its market position, harming franchisees, consumers, and workers. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation. The consumer organisations claim franchisees are locked into long contracts and lease premises at above market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh has appeared in Holywood to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve.  Initially a social media hashtag campaign started by Bangor Elim Church, it went viral after his diagnosis and surgery to remove a large primary cancer and smaller growths.  The campaign, intended to garner support and prayers, has received phenomenal support globally, with social media updates being seen by over 79,000 people.  A mystery donor funded a billboard in Holywood playing fields as part of this support, and Joshua is also receiving support from his classmates and others worldwide.

The UK military buildings are being reorganised and regiments are being resettled, which includes the closure of Brecon Barracks. Conservative MP Chris Davies has condemned this decision, highlighting the barracks' long history since 1805 and its importance to the town.  Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan as part of this reorganisation in Wales. Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the restructure but raised concerns about the impact on people's livelihoods.

This passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It suggests that Britain might need to allow EU fishing boats in UK waters as part of a Brexit deal, despite fishing communities voting heavily for Brexit and hoping to regain control of UK waters.  The UK fishing industry views the EU's Common Fisheries Policy negatively and sees Brexit as an opportunity, but a report highlights that continued access to EU markets is crucial for the UK, as they export most of their fish to the EU. This market access may come at the cost of allowing EU fishing in UK waters. The report also advises retaining some elements of the CFP post-Brexit and warns about potential issues like fragmented fisheries management within the UK. While some in the fishing industry remain optimistic about Brexit, the government aims to balance trade and fisheries management in negotiations.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks about US surveillance programs. These leaks showed that the NSA has extensive access to individuals' online data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data.  The US government also requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call details.  Prism, another program, provided "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies, though these companies deny involvement.  The US government defends these operations as necessary for national security, while critics raise concerns about privacy violations.  There are questions about data protection laws and the extent to which governments monitor citizens, with debates about balancing security and privacy.  The EU has expressed concern about the implications for EU citizens, and privacy groups highlight the potential for widespread privacy violations due to the location of major tech companies in the US.

Open AI is backed by notable figures and companies including Elon Musk and Peter Thiel. Open AI aims for its research to have a "positive human impact" without financial obligations. Some scientists and figures like Musk and Hawking have warned about AI potentially threatening humanity, while other experts believe the threat is remote. Open AI aims to advance AI to benefit humanity, distributing it safely and broadly, acknowledging both its potential benefits and risks. Only a small fraction of their pledged funding will be used in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, based in Doncaster, was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. He carried the Olympic torch on 26 June and received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the 5,000 limit.  Despite a brain injury that initially affected his speech, he now speaks unaided and his personality and humour remain. He spends considerable time in gym and rehab, walks with crutches, and raises money for military charities, including Pilgrim Bandits. His mother reports overwhelming support and friend requests, with his Facebook page receiving thousands of hits. Facebook suggests he consider a public page due to the high volume of requests. The Olympic torch relay involves 8,000 people carrying the flame over 8,000 miles in 70 days, culminating in the London Olympic Games opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, which accounted for 46.2 million Americans. This rate remained the same after increases in the three years prior.  The real median income of households decreased by 1.5%. For a family of four, the average poverty threshold in 2011 was $23,021. Income inequality rose by 1.6% in 2011, marking the first annual increase in the Gini index since 1993.  The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.  In 2010, poverty in the US reached a record high of 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, aged 25, who moved from Somerset to the Red Rose in 2013, has extended his contract with the club until 2019. He is a short-format specialist known for scoring England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan last year. Cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent, his contribution to Lancashire's T20 Blast win, his positive influence in the dressing room, and his international experience. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are for sale and currently located in Portsmouth Harbour.  The deadline to register interest was 23 January, and no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Bids are being finalised, with viewings in late February and March, and a final decision is expected in the spring. The Disposal Services Authority wants to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the UK industry's capacity.  Penny Mordaunt MP hopes at least one ship can be saved, suggesting a reef or diving attraction, while also supporting UK recyclers. The Ministry of Defence aims for the best financial return from the sale. Type 22 frigates were originally designed as anti-submarine ships but evolved into powerful combat vessels.

Fiji has experienced racial and political tensions since 1987, stemming from coups in 1987, 2000 and 2006. These coups were triggered by conflicts between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, harming the economy and Fiji's international reputation. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to a lack of progress towards democracy but was re-instated after elections in 2014. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians with minimal mixing between groups. Fiji's economy relies on sugar and tourism but is diverse, although it experiences trade and budget deficits and receives significant aid.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable, despite missing a deadline. Mr. Mekdad reported that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice, and blamed "terrorist groups" for intercepting a second shipment. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of barrel bombs, while denying the Syrian government bombs civilian areas and accusing the US of supporting terrorists. Reports from the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and the Aleppo Media Centre claim civilian deaths in Aleppo due to barrel bombs. Conflicting reports exist regarding control of Aleppo's central prison, with state media denying rebel seizure and other groups claiming rebel control.  The removal of Syria's chemical weapons is behind schedule, with only 4% removed so far, causing concern from the US and Russia. The OPCW acknowledges security concerns are slowing the process, but Syria insists it is committed to its obligations.

The Booker Prize winner will be announced in London on Tuesday night. Mukherjee's 'The Lives Of Others' is the favourite to win. This year is the first time the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. Shortlisted authors include Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan.

PJS is appealing to the Supreme Court against a ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments to decide whether to grant an appeal and if so, whether to allow or dismiss it.  An interim injunction preventing publication of his identity remains in place until the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish a story about alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but PJS argues for a right to privacy. The Court of Appeal lifted the ban because the details were already widespread online and in other countries, making a permanent injunction unlikely.

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was purchased in August for ÃÂ£345.5m.  There are plans to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. The new owners met with the Blaby District Council to discuss planning questions and aim to improve Fosse Park as a gateway to the city. The new owners want to address parking and congestion issues and believe the park has become tired, aiming to improve common areas and facilities.

The film 'Beauty and the Beast' release in Malaysia was delayed for content review due to a "gay moment". The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the screening with a minor edit to this moment, despite homosexual activity being illegal in Malaysia.  The director described the moment as involving the character LeFou and his feelings for Gaston.  The decision to review the film was criticised.

Landlords letting to more than three unrelated people require a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs Â£1,000, to avoid fines up to Â£20,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. HMO tenants are concerned about eviction and poorly maintained properties due to a shortage of affordable housing. National HMO licensing is for houses of three storeys or more with five or more unrelated people, whereas Southampton's licensing affects specific areas introduced in 2013 and 2015.  Most landlords cooperate, but some resist, resulting in prosecutions by the council.

Following an election almost two months ago, Fine Gael and Fianna FÃ¡il are trying to avoid another election.  Fianna FÃ¡il will facilitate a minority government but not support a programme for government. Water charges are a main issue with Fianna FÃ¡il wanting to remove them and Fine Gael wanting to keep them. A commission to consider Irish Water is a proposal.  No party was able to form a majority government after the election where Fine Gael got 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23 and the Labour Party got seven, and TDs have failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento ship caught fire en route to Valencia. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital. The fire started on a car deck about 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon, and the cause is unclear.  Several ships assisted, and passengers boarded the ferry Puglia. Rescued passengers are returning to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists will provide counselling. The Sorrento may sink. The ship is owned by Atlantica di Navigazione and sent distress signals at 13:50 local time. Initially, the captain did not think evacuation was needed, but it became necessary due to the fire's intensity.

The Electoral Commission raised concerns about potential duplicate voting in the June election and recommended better integration of electoral registers to address this issue.  Despite record voter registration (46.8 million) and high turnout, a surge in online applications resulted in many duplicates due to system limitations and lack of verification.  The Commission suggested clearer information and verification functions on registration sites. Labour cautioned against solutions that might hinder young voter registration, despite acknowledging the seriousness of double voting.

Lawrence Phillips, aged 40, is believed to have killed himself. He was a star football player in college and played in the NFL for teams including the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers.  After his NFL career ended in 1999, he had continued legal problems and was imprisoned for assault, including driving his car into teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend.  While serving a prison term of more than 30 years, he was accused of killing his cellmate and a judge found enough evidence to try him for this.

Private Derby XXX was promoted to lance corporal for good behaviour at an event in Chester marking the Mercian Regiment's eighth year. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams. Private Derby XXX is a Swaledale ram and the 30th mascot ram in a line dating back to the mid-19th Century. The first Private Derby was acquired in 1858, and Private Derby XXX joined in 2014. He has an army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays. He has also switched on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund in a dramatic match described as a classic.  Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp inspired his team to overcome a 2-0 deficit, echoing the spirit of the 2005 Istanbul Champions League final.  The win, secured by a late goal from Dejan Lovren, moves Liverpool closer to Champions League qualification via the Europa League, and highlighted Klopp's impact in instilling belief in the team and fans. The atmosphere at Anfield was exceptional, contributing to Liverpool's comeback against a strong Dortmund side managed by Thomas Tuchel.

Following a meeting in London, Mr Davis of the UK government said they would update Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland on negotiations and proposed monthly meetings for information sharing. Mr Russell of the Scottish government stated that transparency about UK government plans was needed, particularly regarding the single market and customs union. Mr Russell highlighted single market membership as essential for Scotland's economy. The Scottish government will oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal concerning Article 50.

This passage describes a study being conducted on a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including one named Daisy, at the University of Nottingham. These sheep include four clones, Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane, who are considered identical twin sisters to Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. The study is examining these cloned sheep to understand if cloned animals age normally and to investigate concerns about potential "age-memory" in cloned cells, which could lead to premature aging and diseases like osteoarthritis. The research is focused on assessing the prevalence of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis in these sheep, and the results of the study are anticipated to have significant implications for the future of cloning.  The sheep in the study are approaching 9-10 years old and currently appear to be healthy.

John Gosden's unbeaten horse won a race and is aimed for Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks, for which Enable and Coronet are contenders. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes. Shutter Speed, trained by Gosden, secured her fifth Musidora win for Gosden and Dettori and is targeted for France's Oaks. Gosden is concerned about the ground for Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will inspect the course, with Cracksman's participation in doubt due to the proximity to the Derby.

The pound's value fluctuated, initially slipping before recovering and then falling again, while investor uncertainty reached levels seen during the 2008 financial crisis.  The pound decreased against the dollar, euro, and yen as investors grew concerned about the reduced likelihood of a Remain vote in the upcoming referendum and global economic anxieties. Polls indicated a close race with 10 days remaining until the vote, and the probability of a Remain vote has decreased. Experts anticipate increased pound volatility as polls remain tight, with hedge funds betting against the pound and markets on "Brexit alert." Asian stock markets declined due to concerns about the economic impact of leaving the EU, and the FTSE 100 also fell.  The Leave campaign argues the pound is up since March and a weaker pound benefits exporters, noting a recent narrowing of the UK trade deficit.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-off spots.  After a loss to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games, The Iron's losing run is now at three games. Despite this, Cowley remains positive about The Iron's performance this season, acknowledging they are a part-time team facing a tough challenge.

From April 2015, politicians in local councils will be responsible for most planning decisions, moving the responsibility from the Planning Service. This is viewed by some as an opportunity for local councils to develop their communities. However, there are concerns about fairness and transparency, referencing past issues in the 1960s with housing allocation.  Friends of the Earth warn about potential discrimination and close relationships between developers and politicians, emphasizing the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency, particularly regarding political donations. Some politicians oppose the move due to donor security concerns, while others find current donation limits irrelevant. The decision to increase transparency in political donations rests with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg, resulting in amputation.  Teenie was found injured by her owner Sarah Nisbett in Winchburgh on Friday 14 March at about 16:30 and taken to the Scottish SPCA.  The Scottish SPCA and Mrs Nisbett are concerned and want to find the person responsible. The Scottish SPCA believes this incident highlights the need for the Scottish government to implement airgun licensing, despite a consultation last year where a majority opposed the plan.

Benteke has become Liverpool's second most expensive signing, agreeing to a long-term contract. Liverpool triggered a release clause to sign the 24-year-old, making him their seventh summer signing after selling Raheem Sterling. Benteke scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, and stated he joined Liverpool to win trophies and be part of the manager's project. Liverpool struggled for goals last season and manager Brendan Rodgers hopes Benteke will revive their attack, with former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge believing Benteke will do well at Liverpool.

This study found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablets, despite their rapid growth in schools. Tablets are used in a majority of primary and secondary schools, with higher usage in academy schools.  Although head teachers reported a positive impact and tablets may motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement, researchers could not definitively link tablets to improved results.  A separate study suggested touch-screen computers help boys and poorer pupils learn to read.  The study also found high tablet use is linked to internet "addiction" and device use in bed for social media among pupils.

Growing Up in the City is an exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool featuring 25 photographs. These photographs capture the lives of children in Liverpool over 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes images of children at play and at work, showing both the good and bad experiences of childhood. It is open until 25 September.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a rival National League team. Keating, a 21-year-old striker recommended by Micky Adams, has joined Gulls, pending international clearance, and has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps previously. Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as hungry to prove himself. Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won one of their last six matches.

A new law in Bolivia permits children from 12 years of age to work if they have parental authorisation. This law, according to Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, reflects the needs of Bolivia as a poor nation and also increases the punishment for violence against children, setting a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide.  The Vice-President stated this law balances Bolivia's reality with international treaties, acknowledging that over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work due to poverty.  Although the International Labour Organisation generally advises against child labour for those under 15, the Bolivian government believes this law is more enforceable in their country, but the ILO is reviewing if it breaches international regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, aged 50, experienced a heart attack after looking up "women's heart attack symptoms" online when she felt ill at home.  She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99 per cent blocked artery. Her symptoms included nausea and aches, and later chest ache, nausea and fever after helping someone.  She described her heart attack as a "widow maker" and warned readers to know the symptoms and call 911, which she did not do.  She previously hosted The Rosie Show, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

A boy named Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was stabbed and died after a scuffle in an alleyway in Kenton at about 00:30 GMT, following a fight at a party he attended on Saturday evening. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital in stable condition. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, and a 14-year-old boy is being held for possession of an offensive weapon. Police are investigating and appealing for witnesses who were near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate.

The passage describes how Denmark reorganised its patient diagnosis system, particularly for cancer, due to poor survival statistics compared to other European countries.  A key issue was long waiting times for diagnosis, especially for cancer cases with vague or difficult to diagnose symptoms.  To address this, Denmark introduced a three-route system: fast-track routes for obvious cancer symptoms, diagnosis centres for unclear symptoms, and "yes-no" centres for minor symptoms. This new system aims to improve diagnosis speed, reduce "ping pong" between GPs and specialists, and ultimately improve cancer survival rates. Wales is studying this Danish model to potentially improve its own healthcare system.

The UK government has decided to disband the OFT, and Powys will take over some of its responsibilities regarding estate agents. Powys will be able to issue warnings and banning orders to estate agents who are dishonest or break estate agent laws. Powys won a competitive bid to deliver this service and will receive Â£170,000 a year. People with complaints should still contact their local authority trading standards, who may refer cases to Powys if they believe the Estate Agents Act has been breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team and hopes this will lead to more contracts for Powys in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, based on a Nuffield Trust review, to reshape the NHS workforce to address staff shortages. The review found nurses and pharmacists are already filling in for doctors and GPs. This plan aims to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and GP shortages, and is seen as important due to the changing nature of care towards long-term conditions.  While the Nuffield Trust highlights opportunities in reshaping the workforce and improving patient care, they acknowledge that funding is needed for training. Unions and medical leaders warn against using this as a quick fix for staff shortages and emphasize the importance of doctor training and adequate funding for training.

A crash at 03:00 GMT caused Avon and Somerset Police to close the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT after causing disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations are ongoing into the collision. First bus services were affected, but parts of services have resumed a normal schedule and a full service is expected for the evening commute.

NRW estimated the lagoon would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. TLP disputed NRW's figures, stating they had no clear scientific basis and that NRW refused to share their methodology. TLP claimed their modelling estimated a worst case scenario of 2% of all fish species dying. The Swansea tidal lagoon project is a test bed for larger projects. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability. The Welsh Government is supportive but needs clarity from the UK government. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism and stated their figures were based on the best available evidence.

A new agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland was announced by Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster.  This body, developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, is intended to benefit the agri-food sector, which is described as "hugely important" to Northern Ireland with almost 100,000 jobs.  Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, noting the sector's importance for export-led economic growth and the need for better marketing coordination.  While seen as positive, Ms O'Neill mentioned potential implications for other organisations and wants to discuss plans with the Agri-Food Strategy Board.

The Woodland Trust has organised a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon. This is part of a four-year project creating four new woods across the UK to plant millions of native trees commemorating WW1 deaths. At Brackfield Wood, the aim is to plant 40,000 trees to remember the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in WW1. The public are invited to participate and plant trees, and are advised to wear welly boots. The trees are intended to be a tribute to those from Ireland who were involved in WW1.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday for her book "Someone Else's Skin", which is about domestic violence and honour crime. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator. The awards were given at the start of the North Yorkshire crime writing festival. Ann Cleeves described Hilary's book as "finely written and tightly written" and said VI Warshawski was a "game changer".

Santner broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016.  Worcestershire's director of cricket Steve Rhodes stated that losing Santner was a massive blow to their hopes of qualifying. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Test cricket in 2015, will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy in England. Santner enjoyed his time at Worcester but was frustrated by his injury and is looking forward to returning. In August, Worcestershire signed John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring died in Kiev in 2008 after being hit by a speeding car while hailing a taxi.  His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had gone back to a restaurant. A coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating the car had stolen plates, did not brake, and Mr. Pring was likely inebriated.  The coroner and a friend of Mr. Pring believe he was murdered.  His family suspects his wife, Anna Ziuzina, who is 19 years younger than him, was involved to inherit his assets, which she tried to claim quickly after his death.  She misrepresented herself when they met and took actions like selling his belongings after his death.  Ukrainian police initially closed an inquiry but reopened it as a murder inquiry, which is still active but not actively pursued.  Witnesses in Kiev described the incident as a deliberate act, and the car was speeding without lights at 75mph.

Charlie Fearns from Merseyside needs to travel to Seattle for T-Cell Therapy because it is not available in the UK and his previous transplant failed. An anonymous donor has paid for this treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital, which has overwhelmed Charlie's mother. Charlie has been ill since the age of three and after a relapse in April, there were no UK treatment options left. His family were heartbroken when the first transplant failed. The family received confirmation of the donation from the hospital via email and treatment will start as soon as possible.

Apple has implemented a security measure to prevent third-party software from accessing iCloud and stealing photos. This measure is a two-step verification process for accessing iCloud backups, which requires a code in addition to a password. While currently optional, experts suggest this should be the default setting. A recovery key is provided as a backup access method, but concerns exist about its security and usability.  Software from Elcomsoft was used to exploit the vulnerability, but they acknowledge Apple's new security measure is effective. Apple will encourage users to use two-factor authentication more actively.

A deal is being discussed where Wright could buy 20% of Billericay club and become a club director. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off place. Wright previously played non-league football and was runner-up in I'm A Celebrity. Billericay were recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing Â£10,000 a week, and they have signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into warehouse working practices at his Derbyshire company.  MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee, has written to Mr Ashley requesting his attendance at a meeting to discuss these issues, which are under review by the committee. Mr Ashley has not agreed to any of the proposed dates and if he fails to respond, the committee may take further action. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, but previously stated they would review worker rights under Mr Ashley's oversight.

This report, entitled Putin. War, was completed by opposition politician colleagues led by Ilya Yashin. The report accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine, using facts already available in Russian and foreign media since 2014.  The report states that Russian soldiers and equipment were key to rebel victories, contradicting Russia's claim that only volunteers are involved.  Soldiers admitted to being directed by Russian generals and being paid.  Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53bn roubles.  Publishing the report is difficult, and the opposition believes Putin uses the war to boost his popularity, despite previous reports from the politician failing to cause protests.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. The 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are in custody.

Carwyn Jones complained about not seeing the Article 50 letter before it was published, which he found unacceptable and indicative of a lack of respect from the UK government towards devolved administrations.  Alun Cairns responded by stating the UK government has been discussing the letter's contents for months and is acting in the interests of the whole UK. Mrs May mentioned in the letter that devolved administrations should expect a significant increase in decision-making power, prompting questions about which powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them.  The specifics of these devolved powers remain unclear.

On Friday night in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry, two cars were damaged. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community".  The PSNI reported on Facebook that police were "carrying out duties" when attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's location and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board stated they do not expect him to return.  Mr. Charney's lawyer claims statements against him are false and accuses the company of invasion of privacy and extortion. The company's court filing documents evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts from Mr. Charney, in response to his defamation lawsuit. The company states Mr. Charney violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies and believes no board would hire him due to the risks. The company was granted a restraining order against Mr. Charney to prevent negative statements and attempts to remove board members.

Coverage of the game will be available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app.  GB will play Greece at the Copper Box, after Greece won their previous match 92-64. Three players from the Greek team will be absent for this game. This is GB's only home game before competing at FIBA EuroBasket 2017 in September, which starts with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey.  After playing Greece, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website from 17:30-19:30 (BST).

The passage describes a time when phones were mainly used for calls, before the introduction of the Apple iPhone.  The author recounts being asked to feature the new iPhone in a news piece, which was initially difficult due to its unavailability.  The author was able to preview the iPhone thanks to Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and featured it in a news report, leading to some controversy about product placement. The author defended the coverage by arguing the iPhone represented a significant shift, comparing it to the impact of the Model T Ford.  The passage highlights the iPhone's revolutionary impact on photography and mobile activities due to its user-friendly interface, marking the beginning of the mobile connected era and paving the way for further innovations from companies like Amazon and Google.

Cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire near Victor Avenue have ingested a toxic substance. Tests confirmed this and seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday. Three other cats in the area died in the last seven days, and another cat died two weeks prior. Meereen's owner described symptoms and a vet confirmed antifreeze poisoning. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is appealing for safe storage of chemicals and antifreeze.

Despite the Greek government agreeing to further austerity measures, there are no protests in Athens. Greek resorts are experiencing a tourism boom.  It is questioned why Greeks are not protesting against painful austerity measures like VAT increases and pension cuts.  This calm may be before the revelation of the terms of a new â¬86 billion bailout deal.  Despite failing to end austerity, Prime Minister Tsipras remains popular. Greece is suffering from a severe economic downturn with bank closures and lack of credit, which will further impoverish the population.  For the bailout to lead to genuine recovery, debt forgiveness is needed from creditors.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell, is returning to EastEnders for a brief period for Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell.  Peggy Mitchell's character will be killed off due to cancer, which she revealed to her son Phil upon her return to Albert Square after leaving in 2010. Grant Mitchell is returning to reunite with his brother Phil and say goodbye to his mother Peggy, as the Mitchell brothers face losing their mother.  Producers are anticipating classic episodes with the reunion of Grant and Phil Mitchell.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and killed Alice Ruggles.  Her parents knew Dhillon was responsible when police informed them of her death. Dhillon was obsessed with Alice. Alice's mother feels guilt for not taking the situation seriously. Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and received a minimum sentence of 22 years.

French firm EDF approved funding for the Â£18bn Hinkley Point project, but the UK government announced a review of this. This development surprised EDF and caused uncertainty. Critics of the plan have concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments as Chinese investors are providing one third of the funding. The nuclear industry is urging the government to make a decision quickly to avoid potential energy supply problems. Hinkley Point is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity and EDF views it as beneficial. However, there have been financial concerns within EDF, leading to resignations. Environmental groups are critical of the project's value for money and advocate for renewable energy investment instead. The project has been in development since at least 2006 with construction approved in 2013.

A newly designed divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers are concerned this will add conflict and complexity to divorce cases, though the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name this person.  Guidance on the form indicates it is "not normally necessary" to name the third party.  Naming the person makes them part of the court case, potentially causing delays and increased costs.  In 2015, adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces in England and Wales.  Lawyers report clients often want to name the new partner, but are generally advised against it.  The Ministry of Justice clarifies that naming the person has always been possible but not obligatory, and this is also clear in the new form.

Ministers are believed to be focusing on the environment too much at the expense of trees grown for timber. Britain is the world's third largest importer of wood. Commercial forestry organisations are being encouraged to invest in woodland creation. Confor warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting. The forestry industry in Wales is worth over Â£450m a year to the Welsh economy. There is conflict between environmental policy and commercial forestry, with ministers wanting more native broadleaf trees and better access, while conservationists are against commercial forests. The Welsh government wants a balance between environmental, economic and social factors in forestry development and points to the Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy. Confor believes environmental aspects are seen as more important than commercial forestry and that the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland, with only 90 hectares planted last year when 20,000 hectares a year are needed. There is a large market for timber, but saw millers need more timber to increase production.

A boy was badly injured in an incident in Coatbridge on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. Emergency crews attended the scene and the boy was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. His condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attachÃ© Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans. Able seaman Charles Lewis, 91, said he was "honoured and delighted". The Arctic Convoys were vessels travelling from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II, facing threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and thousands of Allied seamen lost their lives. The Russian embassy stated the convoys allowed Russian soldiers to defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front and that the medals were a recognition long expected by the veterans and important for Russia as an expression of wartime alliance.
