Drilling by Cuadrilla has been suspended as a precaution after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, which is the second tremor in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will examine data before a decision is made on resuming drilling. The BGS stated a tremor on 1 April shared a "similar location and mechanism". Shale gas drilling, known as "fracking", is described as shattering rocks to release gas. Cuadrilla has stopped operations to consult with authorities and experts, and this is expected to take a number of weeks. Fracking is controversial due to environmental concerns, but a UK committee supports it with regulation. The BGS is monitoring fracking and notes that injecting water during fracking can cause earthquakes, which is a possible cause of the two recent earthquakes in Lancashire.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud at Liverpool Crown Court. This occurred when he played bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015.  He was accused of giving the impression he was collecting cash for the charity, although he stated he was busking and the banner was a tribute. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed he allowed Carpenter to design the banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town won 3-0 against QPR. Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence scored for Ipswich. QPR keeper Alex Smithies' mistake led to Ipswich's second goal. QPR offered little attack, although Sandro hit the post late on. Ipswich moved up to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th.

Wells, aged 23, performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with a strike rate of 138.66 at an average of 28.69. Wells believes the club is progressing positively and is excited about it. He also thinks the coaches have created an environment of elite performance which is desirable to players.

The Reds, who are fifth in National Two South, won against third-placed Chinnor 29-12, marking their second consecutive win.  Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were highlighted for their performance. Coach Churcher praised the team's front row and front five for their tackling.  The Reds will next play seven teams below them in the league and league leaders Old Elthamians in their upcoming eight games. Churcher believes the team can still improve despite the recent win.

Nazrul, also called Nazu, a 28-year-old man alleged to be a Bangladeshi citizen, is accused by police of raping a 74-year-old nun. He was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. This incident caused outrage in India and resulted in street protests. Nazrul's arrest is the sixth in this crime, with police having identified eight suspects in total, two of whom are still untraced.  Five previously arrested accused have identified Nazrul as the person who raped the nun. Police acted on a tip off that Nazrul, who fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage, was returning to Kolkata by train.  Milon Sarkar was previously arrested in May and described as the leader of the gang involved in the attack which occurred on 14 March in Ranaghat town. During the attack, money was stolen, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped in the convent.

This interactive video with Robert Opie from the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explains the primary reasons for changes in what people buy.  Factors such as domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports have influenced popular items among UK consumers. The video also explores changes in brand ownership and rankings within the UK. A non-interactive version of this content is available.

Two incidents are described where women were tricked by individuals claiming to be from BT technical support. In both cases, the scammers gained remote access to the women's computers and stole money. The first incident happened to a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills on September 15th. The second incident happened in Stranraer seven days later. Police are warning people to be careful about cold calls requesting remote computer access and to never give out banking details over the phone.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, who are third in the Championship league, after leaving Swinton Lions.  He is the Scotland assistant coach and will lead Featherstone in their game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers.  Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's coaching abilities at Swinton. Duffy had a 16-year playing career for Leigh, Widnes and Salford. Stuart Littler has replaced Duffy at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, medic, and coastguard helicopter were sent to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to rescue a rider. The rider had head injuries, was very cold and unconscious. She was treated and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A decision was made at a UN conference in Geneva to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system, aiming to improve the current ground-based radar system. This decision was made by representatives from over 160 countries at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), organised by the ITU, and was prompted by the disappearance of flight MH370, which exposed weaknesses in air navigation systems. The new system will use satellites to receive transmissions, enabling real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world. The ICAO has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will include aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes, or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, was found at age 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and is being held in an Ohio jail. The FBI received a tip on 30 October that this teenager might be the missing child after college application issues.  Authorities confirmed his identity with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Julian's mother was notified. Bobby Hernandez is also charged with tampering with records and is being held at Cuyahoga County Jail with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez was the culprit at the time of Julian's disappearance in August 2002, when he said he was taking his son to pre-school but then fled.

A fire occurred at a site in Duncan Street on 2 March, causing train service reductions and travel delays.  Following the fire, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste and decided to revoke their environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed.  The fire service stated the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, although they had raised concerns to the EA in February about potential fire impacts. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has put forward two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, specifically Crimea. The first bill proposes new provisions for Russia to accept a territory into the Russian Federation if there is a referendum or a plea from the territory's leaders, especially if a state is seen as disintegrating. The second bill aims to speed up the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking ones, by removing requirements such as state tax, previous residence in Russia, sufficient funds, and the need to give up Ukrainian citizenship. This bill is intended to support Ukrainians facing a perceived "brown threat" and would allow them to apply for Russian passports at diplomatic missions before 1 August and gain citizenship in two months. The fast-track passport plan was announced in Sevastopol by A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov, and several Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea.

McLaren, a Formula 1 team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently facing difficulties.  Their slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, which are now resolved, but they are now struggling with the Honda power-unit.  McLaren previously had great success with Honda, including a dominant period from 1988-1991 with drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost.  They experienced further success with Mercedes engines in 1998-99.  Despite past scandals and periods of decline, McLaren, under Ron Dennis, believes they can return to championship-winning form, with Fernando Alonso believing the Honda partnership is his best chance for another title.  McLaren believes their car is good and Honda will improve their engine, expecting future success.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, was discovered badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. The 44-year-old from Everton had been shot in the head and chest and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29 and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody for questioning. Mr Baker was shot after leaving Phoenix Gym at the market. Police believe the shooters waited outside the gym for about an hour. A silver VW Polo, which left the scene quickly, is being searched for by police. Detectives are appealing for people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward as they may have key information.

This passage discusses various ways to engage with Christmas online in a spiritual manner. It highlights Everyday Church Online, a virtual church service with a global reach that streams sermons and has a chat room.  It also mentions Guardians of Ancora, a free fantasy game for children that uses Bible stories, including nativity quests for Christmas.  The passage further describes successful online nativity videos, such as Viral.de's social media-based video and the Churches Advertising Network's video, although the latter was rejected by cinemas for being too religious. Finally, it mentions Next Manga's Manga Messiah, a Manga version of the nativity story available as an app and e-book, and the broader trend of churches using social media to connect with communities and share spiritual messages during Christmas.

An eight-day hearing is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land in Ebbw Vale. Backers have offered around 320 hectares of replacement land. There are conflicting expert opinions on whether the development would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it "difficult to conclude" the replacement land is of equal value but is not opposing the development. An ecology report by developers claims a "net gain" in biodiversity, which the Gwent wildlife trust argued against. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation before Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

Following a report by Novaya Gazeta on 1 April stating that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of homosexuality and at least three killed, Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April and declared the report insulted their faith and Chechen men's dignity. They stated that retribution would occur, which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a threat to journalists and urged Russian authorities to protect them. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's truth, stating detainees were tortured. Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya, but the Chechen spiritual leader confirmed the "retribution" statement. Novaya Gazeta's editor defended their reporting and offered dialogue, while the LGBT Network is helping people flee and may take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia does not prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions receives benefit payments by housing single homeless men found by the charity Fresh Start Housing.  Neither organisation acts illegally, but a homeless group criticises their relationship. Investing Solutions profits by charging housing benefit per person in a property, exceeding the rent paid to the landlord. Both are based in the same building and were set up by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions is a large, profitable recipient of housing benefit, focusing on men over 35. Tenants have reported poor living conditions. Wandsworth Council is a major payer of benefit to Investing Solutions and states they monitor the private rented sector. Crisis charity criticises the setup. Samir Patel defends the organisations, and Fresh Start Housing provides figures on people housed. The Department for Communities and Local Government states local authorities are responsible for safeguarding taxpayer money.

Great Britain, coached by Joe Prunty, played a warm-up match where Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon scored 13 points.  GB led for most of the first three quarters but the Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, took the lead in the fourth quarter and won the game.  This was GB's final warm-up before their Eurobasket qualifying campaign, which starts with a game in Hungary midweek. Coach Prunty stated the key to the qualifiers is competing on every play and felt they lost some fire in this game, but was pleased with Gordon's performance.

This passage discusses the request from former five-weight world champion McGregor to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) for a waiver to use 8oz gloves instead of the standard 10oz gloves for his upcoming fight, a request Mayweather also desires. The NAC will debate this on August 16th, emphasizing fighter safety as their priority.  NAC director Bennett approved the fight after reviewing McGregor's information, citing reasons such as McGregor's UFC rival Nate Diaz's boxing ability, McGregor's physical advantages over Mayweather, and Mayweather's lack of recent knockouts. McGregor's preparation included hiring boxing referee Joe Cortez, and a sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi that led to controversy.

Fleet Street, historically known as the center of British newspapers, is seeing the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, where reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith worked.  Fleet Street was once a very important place for public information, with the first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, published there in 1702.  At its peak, it was the pinnacle of a journalist's career, hosting many national and provincial newspapers.  However, most national newspapers moved away by 1988, adopting new technology.  Fleet Street was known for its lively atmosphere with numerous bars and pubs frequented by journalists.  Now, with the departure of the Sunday Post's journalists, an era of British history has ended, marking the final deadline for Fleet Street's dominance in journalism.

J.K. Rowling stated that comments made to her online reminded her of the world's size and the number of decent people. She mentioned that she had been abused online and believes in standing up to bullies. Rowling faced criticism on Twitter after donating ÃÂ£1m to the campaign against Scottish independence and had also donated the same amount to the Labour party in 2008.  She revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views and had blocked abusive Twitter users she believed were SNP supporters, but had also had positive interactions with other SNP supporters. She also joked about bringing marshmallows if her books were burned. The SNP party's election success is also mentioned.

A study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to face police action and that poverty increases the likelihood of violence in young people.  A history of police trouble is a strong predictor of young people not being in education, employment or training by age 18, and poorer young people are more likely to be under statutory supervision.  Household poverty exacerbates youth offending, and extreme poverty increases the likelihood of being both a victim and perpetrator of crime. Boys are more likely to be violent than girls, and poorer girls are more likely to be involved in violent crime than girls from affluent backgrounds.  Another study in Scottish Justice Matters showed that the fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefitted areas with the most chronic crime, which are often in deprived communities with health and unemployment issues.  Researchers suggest crime is concentrated in poor areas and question if inequality is being adequately addressed. The Scottish government states Scotland is becoming safer and highlights initiatives to tackle poverty.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the Marian estate in Kilkee in the early hours of Sunday and died in hospital. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody. Two other men arrested were released without charge. Mr. Walsh and two others allegedly went to the estate looking for Mr. Haugh, a fight ensued involving weapons, and Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Knives and golf clubs were recovered from the scene. There is tension in Kilkee as a result of the killing.

Phil Flanagan, a Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in May 2014 about Tom Elliott, who is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone and previously served in the UDR. The tweet falsely accused Mr Elliott of harassment and shooting people during his time in the UDR.  Mr Elliott was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Mr Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and has admitted in High Court that the tweet was untrue and without foundation.  Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgement on compensation, and Mr Flanagan's insurance firm has refused to cover his costs in this case. Mr Elliott stated he felt vindicated by the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear has increased sweater production to meet demand, employing over 230 staff. This production boost is due to better than expected sales of their branded range launched in January, alongside growth in their private label business.  The company, established in 1874 and bought by Benny Hartop in November last year, now produces 9,500 sweaters weekly, up from 7,500. This increase is a response to order surges from both domestic and international clients.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, struck Mrs Blackburn with his VW Golf and told Luton Crown Court he had been blinded by the setting sun. Mr. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Mr Wright expressed remorse in court. Mrs Blackburn was a lollipop lady who was hit when escorting a woman and child across the road as pupils left school.  Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light. The trial continues.

This passage describes the NATO exercise "Dynamic Mongoose", which is a response to increased Russian submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships hunting the German submarine U33, which is acting as the enemy, to practice anti-submarine warfare.  This exercise highlights a gap in Britain's defences due to a lack of maritime patrol aircraft, making them reliant on allies and vulnerable to Russian submarines. Russia has a large, advanced submarine fleet and is investing in its military, while some European nations have cut defence budgets. The exercise uses warships, helicopters, and underwater drones to improve NATO's readiness for anti-submarine warfare and underscores the need for Britain to address its defence vulnerabilities.

United Nations officials suggest potential genocide and ethnic cleansing in South Sudan, the world's youngest country. Violence that began in Juba in July has spread, causing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda, exceeding the number of Syrian refugees in 2016.  Daily, 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees, reporting killings, rape, and ethnic targeting, particularly of Equatorians and Nuer by Dinka. Uganda is struggling to cope with the influx of refugees, providing land and shelter in settlements like Bidi Bidi, which has grown rapidly.  The UNHCR is calling for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence, highlighting the dire conditions and trauma faced by refugees, many of whom are children.

McKenzie, aged 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall on 12 November. McKenzie became a professional boxer in 2013 after quitting football in 2011 and has eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is funded by the coalition's Â£330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. The project will cost Â£33m, with the remaining balance being paid by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is cramped and outdated, suffering from being too hot in summer and too cold in winter, with maintenance issues. The new hospital aims to provide a better environment for patient recovery and is planned to be built on land at Bowers Lane, with the aim to be finished by autumn 2014, subject to planning permission.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, close to Sheffield city centre. The incident occurred around 13:35 GMT. The victim was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and died in Northern General hospital.  He was reportedly in or near a black Mercedes car and local residents said he was a member of a local family who were having a family celebration.  This shooting is one of a number of recent shootings in Sheffield, although previous incidents have been in the north of the city.

The passage describes cyber warfare activities related to the conflict between Ukraine and Russia, highlighting three main groups. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukrainian hackers who target Russian and separatist entities using methods like DDoS attacks, hacking servers and financial systems, and monitoring CCTV. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western, pro-Russian group aiming to thwart Ukrainian military plans by hacking Ukrainian government websites, leaking documents, and disrupting systems. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, focuses on leaking documents from the Kremlin, some of which relate to the Ukraine conflict, though their methods of obtaining information are unclear.

Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Mr Salmond bid farewell to the parliament as they are standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. Mr Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was diverse, not divided and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood. Mr McNeil warned Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system. Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of residential care for older people in Wales.  She is asking pensioners, their friends, and families to share their experiences to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess the quality of life and care, considering factors like health, social relationships, and the care home environment.  While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, they are disappointed that no care provider expert is on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, experienced an increase in pre-tax profit by Â£800,000 to Â£3.5m in the year ending June 2016, despite a Â£1m decrease in turnover to just over Â£100m. International sales for the company grew in Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies feeds for multiple sectors including beef, sheep, and poultry, and operates 19 Country Stores in Scotland selling products for farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges the unpredictable outlook for agriculture and the uncertain impact of Brexit, but remains confident in its position.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden. A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, who people are warned not to approach. Ian McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Police are asking for information and have increased patrols in the area.

David Lipton from the IMF has stated that the global economy is weakening and is at a delicate point. This is based on the IMF's reading of the global economy and follows weak trade figures from China. Due to this, the IMF is likely to downgrade its global growth forecast of 3.4% in April. This situation has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that rely on growth in China.

The council held a scrutiny meeting to discuss problems with the new vessel.  The Cowes crossing will be free until 2 July due to problems and to allow feedback, and the council has ordered an audit of the project.  The ferry, launched late on 14 May, has experienced breakdowns, run aground, been suspended due to training issues, and damaged cars.  A shopkeeper expressed concern about business survival and asked about compensation for businesses, which is up for discussion according to a transport councillor. The councillor stated that the issues are teething problems of a prototype and that electrical problems and groundings have been resolved, and ramp extensions are being manufactured to resolve car damage.

A crash involving several vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models in London, a temp agency, advertised for a personal assistant specifying "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup", which the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women".  Women's equality campaigners and the Fawcett Society also criticised the advert as discriminatory and potentially illegal.  An employment lawyer stated such adverts using terms like "beautiful and attractive" could be discriminatory against older women and unlawful.  Matching Models' founder defended their practices by stating "looks are important" to their clients and that "first impressions count".  However, the EHRC countered that important first impressions are not about hair colour and urged the agency to modernise its practices.  The passage highlights that under the 2010 Equality Act, discriminatory job specifications are unlawful.  The founder further justified specific requests by citing client preferences for certain looks, including a client wanting a "Jackie O" look and another wanting blonde, blue-eyed, Greek women. Matching Models' clients include MTV and Louis Vuitton, and the founder claims to have hired 5,000 people worldwide, including models with tattoos and piercings for MTV.

A shooting took place at a hostel of the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, who worked as an office assistant at the school, is accused of shooting 18-year-old Gautami in the head, resulting in her death.  He also shot and severely injured another student, Sirisha, who is believed to be out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April. The motive for the shooting is unclear, and gun crime in Indian schools is described as rare, with a past incident mentioned in 2007 near Delhi.

Glaad analysed television shows between June 2016 and May 2017 and counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16 this year. However, more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters in shows such as Orange is the New Black and Wentworth died or were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television. Glaad's study is called Where We Are on TV and is based on scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series.

Conservative MP for Northampton South, David Mackintosh, announced his decision to step down as MP. This announcement was made before a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed.  This follows reports that millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC, when Mr Mackintosh was council leader, is missing.  The loan of Â£10.25m is under police investigation for "alleged financial irregularities" and a majority of his local party were going to vote to deselect him. Mr Mackintosh stated it was the right time for a new representative after being MP since 2015.

A policeman named Roy Oliver fired a rifle into a car in Balch Springs in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards.  The policeman was sacked for policy violations after the incident, which occurred when police responded to reports of underage drinking at a party.  Police initially claimed the car was reversing aggressively, but footage showed it driving forward. Roy Oliver was charged with murder and aggravated assault of the other teenagers in the car. No trial date has been set, and Roy Oliver is currently free on bail. If convicted of murder, he would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

Melania Trump intends to move to Washington with Barron after his school year finishes, but no date has been specified. This decision has faced criticism, although some support it as responsible parenting. Historically, only Martha Washington and Anna Harrison did not reside in the White House, but Frances Folsom Cleveland lived there only during social season.  Other First Ladies have had school-aged children in the White House, like Chelsea Clinton and the Obama daughters, who moved in at the start of their fathers' presidencies. The role of First Lady is ceremonial, involving hosting and supporting causes, with examples of First Ladies like Michelle Obama actively engaging in initiatives. Some First Ladies, like Nancy Reagan, initially focused on supporting their husbands. There is speculation about Ivanka Trump potentially taking on some First Lady duties.  Past First Families, such as the Clintons and Obamas, have aimed to balance White House life with family life and privacy.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October this year.  The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the initial police response to a call from the man, following instructions from the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS). Pirc will submit a report to COPFS, and Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation.

A yellow wind warning was issued, indicating potential gusts of up to 75mph, particularly west of mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction may increase the wind's impact. Travel disruption on roads and sea is expected in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants played the Panthers in an opening game where Derrick Walser scored for the Giants and Jeff Dimmen equalised for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored for the Giants, and Andy Bohmback equalised for the Panthers. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored for the Giants, and David Ling scored for the Panthers. The two teams will play again on Saturday. Nottingham is leading the league with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers are second with 27 points, and Belfast are third with 25 points.

World champion Hamilton started from the back, broke his front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops. Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with his Ferrari teammate Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth. Raikkonen overtook Hamilton in the closing stages.  Rosberg won the race after Ricciardo, who initially led, suffered a puncture. The race had a chaotic start with multiple first-lap collisions and a safety car. Hamilton faces a 36-point deficit in the championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit to encourage discussion about this topic in German football.  This announcement was praised by former teammates, football administration figures, and others, and is considered a courageous and important step in the fight against homophobia in German football.  While some acknowledged the difficulty of openly discussing homosexuality in football and previous advice existed to remain quiet, there is hope that Hitzlsperger's announcement will lead to greater openness and acceptance in the sport.

Sidwell, aged 34, played 32 Championship games this season for Brighton, aiding their promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years.  His contract is expiring and he is hoping for a new deal to stay with Brighton in the Premier League. Brighton's promotion was confirmed after their win over Wigan and they are aiming to win the league title. Sidwell believes he has performed well and deserves a new contract to play in the Premier League with Brighton again.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester United equalised from a corner after 17 minutes with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made multiple saves throughout the match.  Tom Aldred of Blackpool missed a headed chance. Sean Murray of Colchester United was shown a red card.

Reid, aged 29, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season when they were relegated from League One.  Reid has also played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston. He could debut for the U's on Wednesday in the EFL Cup against Aston Villa. Colchester started this season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday. You can find the latest football transfers on a dedicated page.

A permanent memorial is being built at the National Memorial Arboretum to honour UK police officers and staff. This was prompted by the murder of PC Keith Palmer. The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for Â£1.5m towards the construction, which is set to include over 1,400 names. The memorial will recognise the contribution of policing and provide a place for remembrance for families and colleagues. It will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes for families of fallen officers. The government has committed Â£1m towards the total Â£4m cost and it is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United won 1-0 against Sunderland and are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games remaining.  They have achieved 25 wins out of 30 matches.  Their next league game is against Manchester City.  Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained in the Sunderland game.

Google's Mr Schmidt stated that the company paid legally required taxes, noting they paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011 and that it is up to the government to change the tax system if they want companies to pay more. Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, allowing for secret evidence to prevent hidden tax affairs. Google is criticised for minimising UK taxes by routing sales through Ireland. EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance with information exchange. Mr Schmidt argued taxes should be levied where economic activity and risks occur and called for debate on international tax reform and for politicians to set tax rules.

The regulator, NHS Improvement, wants to see more progress in reducing the NHS agency bill.  Last year Â£3.6bn was spent on agency staff and the regulator wants to reduce this by Â£1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October which has saved Â£600m so far. This cap means hospitals should not pay more than 55% above normal shift rates for most staff, excluding senior managers.  The aim is to reduce costs and reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to agency fees and employer costs.  Progress is "promising" but the NHS is still 10% short of where they want to be.  NHS Improvement will publish league tables on agency spending and collect information on the top 20 highest earners, due to suspicion of overcharging, with examples given of hospitals being quoted double the capped rates for doctors.  NHS Improvement chief executive Jim Mackey stated the NHS cannot afford expensive agency staff and more needs to be done.

Longford Town Centre, intended as a symbol of commerce, is now seen as a monument to economic downturn. Local traders, including Matt O'Brien, indicate business is improving after a downturn, partly due to diversification.  Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's investment choices in the midlands, with Robert Troy highlighting the IDA's lack of promotion of Longford for investment.  The government points to the planned Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, potentially creating 1,000 jobs, as evidence of their support. James Bannon is optimistic about tourism in the midlands.  However, Matt O'Brien suggests that free parking could further boost local business, indicating that while recovery is beginning, more action is needed in the midlands.

This competition concludes on 29 May. There are eight teams participating in the competition, and each team will face each other twice. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. You can follow the scores, fixtures and results on BBC Sport.  Currently, Warner is the leading run-scorer and has hit the most sixes. De Kock has the highest individual score in an innings and McClenaghan has taken the most wickets. Four current or former England players are participating in the tournament, including Eoin Morgan and Kevin Pietersen.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found that plastic bag usage has increased by 200 million since 2013.  These bags are often not recycled, are thrown away, and cause environmental problems in rubbish dumps and rivers. To combat this, from October people in England will be charged 5p per plastic bag to encourage reuse, similar to successful schemes in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland where bag usage has decreased. Campaigners hope this charge will reduce bag waste and help the environment.

Strong winds in Wales caused damage including a school roof being ripped off in Rhosgadfan and power cuts to hundreds of homes.  There were train delays and restrictions on major bridges.  A yellow wind warning was in place until midnight Friday, which was a busy travel day.  The strongest winds were recorded Friday afternoon at Mona on Anglesey.  Irish Ferries cancelled some sailings and Arriva Trains Wales warned of delays.  The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle.  While winds eased Friday evening and some restrictions were lifted, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Jordan told The Hollywood Reporter he is "super excited" about a film project and wants to "put a different spin on it".  He will reunite with his Creed director Ryan Coogler and is looking forward to working with him again, as well as Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o won an Oscar in 2014 and Boseman is currently playing Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. The film, Black Panther, will be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, and BBC studios located in the eastern end of Alexandra Palace are planned to be repaired and refurbished as part of a larger east wing restoration project. The aim is to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The renovated theatre is hoped to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music. The glazed east court will become a public space for exhibitions. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing Â£18.8m and Haringey Council is contributing Â£6.8m towards the Â£26.6m east wing refurbishment project. Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust are aiming to raise the final Â£1m by summer 2017. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery and was originally created for opera, musicals, plays, entertainment and cinema screenings. It is hoped the theatre will reopen in 2018 if funds are successfully raised.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England after his debut in 2009. He was part of the England squads for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played for three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, stated his decision was based on common sense and wished the England team success. His single international goal was scored against Moldova in a 2014 World Cup qualifier match.

A house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, belonging to Marcy Smith and her family, was destroyed by flames.  David, Mrs. Smith's son, woke his family and they escaped, but their pets died. Mrs. Smith believes she and her daughter would not have survived if David had not alerted them, as he saw the flames while on FaceTime. The fire started from rubbish burned in the wood stove, something Mrs. Smith had done many times before. The fire spread very quickly and the fire alarm did not activate. The community has supported the family with donations. Mrs. Smith is very proud of her son for saving them.

An energy drinks giant was considering a Â£200m offer for the Premier League club West Ham. Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in West Ham in 2010, valuing the club at Â£105m and now own more than 85% of it. Since August's move to London Stadium, West Ham have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups.  Sullivan stated last year that a minority shareholding sale was possible to clear debts, but he and Gold intend ownership to pass to their children.

This awards ceremony, which star Jillian Bell stated is "definitely not the Oscars", included fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance. It served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters. The big winner was "The Fault in Our Stars" for best movie, with star Shailene Woodley also winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for "American Sniper", Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for "22 Jump Street", and Meryl Streep won best villain for "Into the Woods". Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award and Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, joined by his Avengers co-stars. Clips from upcoming films "Pitch Perfect" sequel, "Trainwreck", and "Ultron" were shown.

Smith, aged 21, was loaned from Dons to United in July and has scored five goals this season.  Scotland Under-21 player Smith previously debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and scored four goals in 89 appearances. St Mirren boss Jack Ross believes Smith is a "brilliant acquisition" and a good, mature player who will provide another attacking option for the team. St Mirren are bottom of the Championship and will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes because the weather is now warm enough. They aim to fill in 145 potholes each day over four months.  Additionally, extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December, on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland, rigging supervisor Steve Innes and fellow Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while working on pipe equipment during shutdown.  They were not initially given proper protective equipment.  Workers now face cancer fears and are undergoing blood tests, with Mr. Innes claiming EnQuest failed in its duty of care. EnQuest stated that additional precautions have been taken and that the exposure was below reportable levels to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), who confirmed they were aware but did not investigate as it was not reportable under regulations. Wood Group emphasized employee safety and conducted medical assessments. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers and called for transparency.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased an artwork for $650,000 in 2007 from dealer Art of the Past.  The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities.  The artwork, a sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari, is thought to be stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu.  Following discussions and an official request from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), ACM decided to return the sculpture.  ACM acknowledged the dealer's confession of dealing in looted antiquities, despite no conclusive proof of theft for this specific sculpture, and will seek legal compensation for fraud.  This sculpture was one of 30 objects bought from the dealer, with no others thought to be stolen.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in Milan and Florence, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake, with its epicentre in Garfagnana, occurred at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) and was followed by aftershocks. Phone lines and power were disrupted in Garfagnana, and schools were evacuated as a precaution.  This earthquake is described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow", and "came out of nowhere". Italy is still recovering from a past deadly earthquake in L'Aquila, and has experienced earthquakes in the same area previously, including one last May that caused fatalities and damage.

A 62-year-old grandfather named Austin Grant from Sheffield was initially unsure about the climate of South Yorkshire. However, on 8 September 2016, he saw some results that made him very happy, although the fruit was not yet ripe.

Rockstar announced that the release of their game has been delayed until 24 March, from the original date of 27 January.  This delay is for extra testing and polish. Online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release. Screenshots of the PC version have been released, showing greater detail, 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution and triple monitor support. Minimum specifications for PC have been published. Grand Theft Auto V was released on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1bn in three days.

A 76-year-old artist won the ÃÂ£25,000 prize at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery for their painting 'Squint (19)'. The artist had been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, and described winning as "very nice indeed". Judge Ansel Krut called 'Squint (19)' "quite extraordinary" and noted it depicts a leper squint from medieval churches. The artist mentioned the painting is part of a series and its relatively small size of about 7ft was a reason for entering it. The prize money will be used for art materials. Krut described the painting as a "tone poem" with "great sympathy" and stated it was the "best painting". The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is a biennial British art award with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Offices for Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit newspapers were attacked, with no reported casualties. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, starting a blaze that was quickly put out by firefighters. Both buildings had windows shattered by gunfire in night-time attacks that occurred almost simultaneously. Police found spent bullet casings at both locations, which are 20km apart, and are searching for the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. These newspapers support the AK Party of President Erdogan.

A 24-year-old who was contracted with the Stags will join Marcus Bignot's Mariners on a free transfer on 1 January.  He previously played on loan at Crawley for the first half of the season, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. This player, formerly of Burton, is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger has been linked to a job. Southgate replaced Sam Allardyce in September and oversaw a win against Malta and a draw with Slovenia. Wenger said Southgate is a good observer and has experience. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to persuade the Football Association to give him the job permanently. Wenger believes competency is most important for the job and Southgate has an opportunity to show his quality. Wenger also mentioned that Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract at his club, Arsenal, despite interest from other clubs. Finally, Wenger stated that Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry into the incident, and the company is cooperating with the investigation.

A new charter arrangement has been agreed to resolve a long-running dispute over seafarers' pay, where the RMT union claimed some workers were paid less than ÃÂ£4 an hour on freight boats.  The issue involved freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck for Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, but Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap, which Seatruck declined. The new charter will see contracted services return to Serco Northlink next month and ensure all crew members are paid at least minimum wage.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. Mr Mitchell and his mother also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events to police. Mr Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault. Sentencing for Mr Mitchell and his mother will be on 6 February.

Rod Temperton died in London at 66 after a battle with cancer. He was a songwriter known for hits like "Boogie Nights" for Heatwave and "Off The Wall", "Baby Be Mine", "Rock With You", and "Thriller" for Michael Jackson.  Temperton was nicknamed "The Invisible Man" and was born in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire. He started his music career after working in a frozen food factory and joining Heatwave. He later wrote songs for Michael Jackson and won a Grammy in 1990. Tributes were paid by Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, and Chaka Khan.

A team including researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in the Brazilian Amazon. These geometrical "geoglyphs", numbering over 450, were hidden by rainforest until deforestation revealed them.  Their function is not fully understood, but they are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures, and may have been used as ritual gathering places.  Research suggests these geoglyphs were built amongst taller vegetation and that the Amazonian forests were not pristine before European arrival, but influenced by humans for 6,000 years through practices likened to "prehistoric supermarket" agroforestry.  Modern biodiversity in Acre forests may be a legacy of these practices.

Australian tennis player Kyrgios, aged 21, who is ranked 12th in the world, beat world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, said he was tired and bored during the match due to his success in Japan and travel to Shanghai, including poor sleep and a bad journey to the courts. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst, describing the tournament as a "circus".

Scientists and charities say the HPV jab will protect people from head and neck cancers.  The HPV vaccine is currently given to girls to protect against cervical cancer. Charities and organisations are asking the Welsh government to roll out the vaccination, as cases of head and neck cancer are increasing, affecting younger people and mostly men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice on extending the vaccination programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from a rare blood cancer, gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away. He had been documenting his cancer journey on a Facebook page called 'Jak's Journey' which gained over 28,000 likes.  Despite being unwell, Jak briefly attended a school prom held in his honour where he received awards.  His family announced his death on Facebook and highlighted his positive attitude and fight against cancer.  Before his death, Jak met with Rangers FC players and received visits from various sports teams and the cast of Wicked.  After learning his cancer had spread and treatment stopped, Jak and his family focused on raising money for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with a charity football match planned.

Egypt won against Uganda 1-0 with a goal from El Said, assisted by Salah in the 89th minute. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside.  Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is out of the tournament. Ghana has already qualified for the quarter-finals by winning against Mali 1-0 earlier on the same day.

Lancashire County Council is planning to build a railway station in Skelmersdale on land earmarked from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, after a study by Network Rail.  Skelmersdale's original railway station closed in 1956. The plan, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, aims for two direct trains per hour to Liverpool.  A councillor stated the location allows for future expansion and has good access. The council will now start acquiring the land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
Plants were found in an elaborate grow house in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene by police.

A 28-year-old woman was found in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, with serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She was operated on and taken to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, handed himself in to police. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive is unclear and police are investigating and seeking witnesses.

This research study, conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, with a sample size of 4,600 workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise. However, when comparing like-for-like workers, men are 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they ask. The study found no evidence to support the idea that women are more reluctant to ask for pay rises due to being reticent, fearing upsetting their boss, or deviating from stereotypes.  The research, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, also indicated that younger women under 40 are negotiating pay rises as successfully as men in the same age group.

Oxford City Council used funds for ground investigations to find new burial sites, but no suitable location was found.  The cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council is still searching for options because they have run out of suitable land within Oxford.  Identified council-owned sites were unsuitable due to size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants. After the two cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, reserved plots, and ashes interment will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to access online information, including videos and band interviews, from signs and posters at the festival. The festival is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July and will feature acts such as The Waterboys and Imelda May. The app is an augmented reality experience intended to enhance the festival for visitors and allow people worldwide to interact with the festival, access information, buy tickets and experience the festival atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day but collapsed and died after the race. Veterinary staff treated him, but he was pronounced dead, and the British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage".  This type of event is described as rare, even in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had experienced post-race ataxia in the past, but not on this occasion. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014 and was described by his trainer as the "horse of a lifetime".  Although questions were raised about a possible link to his past overheating issues, the report concludes his death was due to a haemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl met a man called David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. The defendant, now called Davina and aged 34, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody in a male prison in Winchester due to risks. The case was described as unusual.  Ayrton raped the teenager in the garage while two others were asleep. The victim clearly recollected the events. In 2014 Ayrton told a care home worker about the attack. Ayrton has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer. Ayrton spoke about her sexuality in court and that she had not made physical changes or taken medication. She changed her name in 2012.

Novak Djokovic lost a doubles match in Rio to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares 6-4 6-4. This loss occurred a day after Djokovic was defeated in the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Prior to the Olympics, Djokovic, the world number one, won his 30th Masters title in Toronto, but he also experienced a surprise defeat at Wimbledon in July to American Sam Querrey.

More than 20 competitors will participate in a chainsaw carving event in Carrbridge this Saturday.  Competitors are from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US. They are only allowed to use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and people shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb has not played rugby since injuring his foot in September. He is close to returning and aims to be fit for the Six Nations in February. He is in pre-season training and hopes to return earlier than the start of February. Wales will play Ireland on 7 February. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, rejecting other offers to stay. He wants to play for Wales and believes staying at Ospreys is the best way to achieve this.

Border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near Sumas, Washington on Tuesday morning. The agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One man fired a weapon at agents and ran, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody. Nathan Hall, the man who ran, was later arrested in Canada. The backpacks contained 58lb of ecstasy. Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The three in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for smuggling.

Childline counselled more than 4,500 children in the past year, an increase from about 2,400 in 2011-12.  The actual number of children experiencing online abuse is believed to be greater. Children as young as seven have reported to Childline being tormented and abused online, causing misery and humiliation. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, stated these figures are a wake-up call, highlighting that cyber-bullying follows children home and adults, parents and teachers must intervene. Schools need to take the issue seriously and children should seek help. This report is released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, who are working to combat the problem.

The postponement of a vote on new homes in settlements was requested by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office before a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This occurred after the US abstained from a UN Security Council resolution against settlement construction, which angered Mr Netanyahu. He accused the White House of helping draft the resolution, a claim denied by the US, who hoped the resolution would be a "wake-up call" for Israel. The resolution stated that settlements, where over 500,000 Jews reside, are illegal under international law and an obstacle to peace. Israel rejected the resolution and was particularly angered by the condemnation of building in East Jerusalem. In response, Mr Netanyahu took diplomatic actions against countries that voted for the resolution. The vote on new homes was postponed to avoid straining relations with Washington before Mr Kerry's speech, where he is expected to discuss ending the conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas stated the resolution helps the upcoming peace conference in France.

To mark the eve of the Queen's 90th birthday, Prince William gave a BBC interview where he described her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch.  A picture of the Queen with Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released for stamps celebrating the birthday. The Queen, with the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, marking the start of birthday events and the postal service's 500th anniversary.  At Alexandra Gardens, they opened a bandstand and met school children. Political leaders like David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn wished the Queen happy birthday. Prince William addressed criticisms about his royal duties, stating he takes duty seriously and sees the Queen as his role model. Ten stamps were released for the birthday, including a stamp sheet with four generations of royals. Birthday events include unveiling The Queen's Walkway and lighting beacons. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama are scheduled to have lunch with the Queen. The Queen celebrates two birthdays annually, her actual birthday on April 21st and an official birthday in June.  The group Republic criticised the BBC's celebratory coverage of the birthday.

West Ham United, a Premier League team, defeated League Two side Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored the goals for West Ham before half-time. Cheltenham had some chances but ultimately did not score, and West Ham could have won by a greater margin. This result means that League Two no longer has any representation in the EFL Cup. This was the second time these two teams have met in this competition, with West Ham winning on both occasions.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, caused the fatal crash by failing to spot McNicholl on his motorcycle when turning right in his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined ÃÂ£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be jailed, believing it was a momentary lapse, and Werner was remorseful.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, is described as a dangerous British jihadist who returned from Syria. He went to Syria in January of last year, calling himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, and joined Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State.  He was involved in online propaganda for the group, including videos and images, some of which were gruesome.  He attempted to return to the UK, faking his death online and being picked up in Bulgaria by his cousin. Upon arrival in Dover, he was arrested. Police consider him dangerous as he went to Syria for terrorist training and concealed his return. He has admitted to four offences and was held in a high-security prison.

Kayden Jackson, aged 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season. He has been signed by Barnsley as their third signing for next season. Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season. Barnsley's caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom said Jackson has pace and will fit in nicely to the way they play.

Bottles started washing up at Poldhu Cove on Sunday and National Trust volunteers are removing them as they are considered a risk to wildlife.  The bottles are sealed, but some are leaking. The National Trust believes a container went overboard from a ship during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated a container of 'Vanish' was lost from the MV Blue Ocean, but there is no current evidence the bottles are from this container. The container is thought to have been lost near Land's End in May. Other coves have also been affected. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is "highly concerned" about the impact on marine life. Cornwall Council and partners are monitoring beaches and the public are advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to recover them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00. Several people received minor injuries. The road was closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland inquiries are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back for Bolton Wanderers, made 14 appearances last season, contributing to their second-place finish in League One and promotion.  Having joined from Charlton in 2014, he has played 83 games for Bolton.  Manager Phil Parkinson highlighted Dervite's excellent contribution at the end of the campaign. Dervite is among players like David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan who have signed new contracts with Bolton after their promotion to the Championship.

The Lib Dem party accused Labour of intending to "concede everything", while Labour responded that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope".  The two parties had previously cooperated to inflict defeats on the government regarding EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected amendments. Labour accused the Lib Dems of "grandstanding", while the Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting a "hard Brexit".  Despite this, the parties have cooperated on other issues in the past and the Lib Dems are optimistic about future cooperation, although Labour predicts "residual tensions".

In the current election, defence is not a priority for most political parties and ranks low in electorate concerns compared to issues like the economy and NHS.  Politicians are hesitant to focus on defence, and manifestos from major parties lack detail on the subject. Despite a more dangerous and unstable world, the UK, like other European nations, has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, reducing army size and naval and air fleets.  UK defence spending has fallen to sixth place globally and is likely to drop below the NATO 2% GDP target, with only smaller parties committed to meeting it.  While further defence cuts are anticipated, some parties are limiting their options due to commitments like Trident replacement.  There is no political consensus on the nuclear deterrent, and its future is uncertain.  The UK is acquiring new aircraft carriers, but there are concerns about manning levels and equipment, raising fears of a "hollow force" and making it harder for the UK to maintain its global military influence.

Barcelona insists they have not committed any offence regarding the signing of Neymar for Â£48.6m, of which Neymar's parents received Â£34m. The total cost of Neymar is estimated to be Â£106.8m.  Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president and is being investigated for misappropriating money.  There are allegations that the actual cost of Neymar was greater than initially stated, leading to ongoing investigations. Barcelona made a tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend their reputation, while maintaining their original tax payment was correct. It is unconfirmed if this payment will stop the investigation.

Michael Luciw, aged 27, died in a car crash as a passenger in a van hit by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died and was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Following this, Mr Luciw's family stated that retired people should have regular driving tests, a view supported by Mr Harrington, the van driver who was injured in the crash. Age UK stated that it was vital for older people to drive for as long as possible.  Currently in the UK, drivers over 70 must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licence, with no medical or driving test required. The DVLA stated they have no plans to restrict licensing based on age as evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause accidents.

The safety of implants used to treat incontinence has been questioned by women due to side effects.  An independent expert, Alison Britton, will examine a report on these implants after concerns were raised about its conclusions, leading to resignations from the review group. The report recommends that these procedures should not be routine for pelvic organ prolapse, and instead, patients should be offered various treatments and information to make informed decisions.  Mandatory reporting of adverse events was also recommended.  Despite calls for a ban, these recommendations will be implemented, though the power to ban the procedures lies with a UK regulatory body, not the government. The chairwoman of the review, Tracey Gillies, apologised for failing to unite the panel around the report, which has been controversial.  Two members of the review group resigned, expressing dismay at the report, and it was claimed that parts of the report were removed.  Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had these implants, and some have suffered complications, with over 400 women taking legal action.

Laura Muir, aged 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record in the 5K at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned if the race met UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking, mentioning concerns about it being a "genuine race" and drug testing. British Athletics stated Muir's time is expected to be officially classified as a record. McColgan praised Muir's ability, suggesting she could run even faster and win world medals, comparing Muir's record-breaking race to her own from 25 years prior. McColgan is pleased that a fellow Scot broke her record and acknowledged Muir's world-class status and previous achievements, including breaking her own British 1500m record and reaching the Olympic final.
Jung won gold aboard Sam in an equestrian event at the Rio Olympics. Astier Nicolas of France won silver, and Phillip Dutton of America won bronze. William Fox-Pitt of GB finished 12th.

Murray, a Briton, won against Fognini, the 29th seed, in four sets: 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes and concluded at 20:57 BST. Murray secured his place in the last 16 for the 11th time and will next play Benoit Paire in the fourth round.  Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also reached the second week. Murray described the match as tense and not his best tennis, mentioning the fading light and the possibility of the roof closing. He acknowledged he needs to improve his movement for his next match.

A sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014 at 06:00 BST led to police finding people still at the bar and evidence of alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. As a result, the bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside of licensing hours. Ms O'Neill was fined Â£3,000 and Mr Thomas was fined Â£1,000. The judge highlighted Ms O'Neill's "appalling record" and the improper management of the bar.

Mike Nesbitt launched the Ulster Unionist party manifesto with the slogan "Domination doesn't work, partnership does". The party wants the election to be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive issue, but focus has shifted to comments made by Mr Nesbitt.  Mr Nesbitt stated he would prefer to go into Stormont with the SDLP rather than Sinn FÃ©in and that he would not withdraw his comments. The manifesto, named 'Real Partnership', includes action on waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community and guaranteeing no group is worse off due to Brexit.  Mr Nesbitt believes the election is about "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption".

A motion confirmed by Justice Minister Claire Sugden will go to the assembly for approval. This motion aims to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, regarding pardons for abolished sexual offences, similar to 'Turing's Law'.  The motion is expected to contain provisions for both posthumous pardons and for living gay and bisexual men.  The Minister secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass this motion to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland compared to England and Wales and to right the wrongs of the past. The motion will now be considered by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second to Faith Kipyegon in a race with a time of four minutes, 19.12 seconds. This time broke Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list. Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio. This was her first 1500m race of the season, and she is balancing training with her veterinary studies.
This passage contains pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland that are ranked as "most excellent" for water quality.

This passage states that barrister Richard Horwell QC believes the Russian state was likely behind the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006, as suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive.  Litvinenko died after drinking tea containing polonium-210 with the suspects, who deny wrongdoing.  The presence of polonium suggests Russian state involvement, though direct orders from Vladimir Putin are not confirmed.  Motives could include Litvinenko's defection to the UK and criticism of Putin.  The suspects left a polonium trail, extradition attempts failed, and they remain in Russia.  The risk to the public from polonium exposure is unknown, and Litvinenko was poisoned twice.

Following the retirement of Michael Clarke, Steve Smith, aged 26, has been appointed as captain. David Warner, aged 28, has been named as vice-captain. Smith's appointment is for an ongoing basis and he will captain the one-day and Twenty20 teams, in addition to the Test team. Smith previously captained in three Tests against India when Clarke was injured. Warner's appointment as vice-captain comes despite past disciplinary issues, with selectors believing he has matured. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the Ashes Test starting on 20 August.

Mr. Farron refused to answer if homosexual sex was a sin. He stated he was passionate about LGBT-plus rights and defending equal marriage would be a top agenda. He also wanted to extend marital rights to transgender people.  When questioned about voting against the Equality Bill in 2007, he stated he supported equality and that the Lib Dems had concerns about the bill regarding "protection of individual liberties".

Sanofi, a French company, closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use this plant for pharmaceutical production and hopes to employ former Sanofi staff. Accord believes this investment will positively impact the area. Councillor Nick Forbes of Newcastle City Council views this as "fantastic news" for Newcastle and the North East, strengthening its science and healthcare sector reputation. He highlights Accord as a global pharmaceutical company whose investment and skilled jobs will boost the local economy. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries globally.

Richard Ellis is leaving his role at the end of his contract on Friday. Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. These departures, according to Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, suggest the council struggles to retain senior staff, and he anticipates further departures. Richard Ellis was the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Mr Monaghan was head of the chief executive's office, and Mr Sutherland was head of human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked all three for their "dedication and professionalism".

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has had mechanical issues.  Martin initially stated he was quitting road racing but clarified he is not quitting racing or road racing, but has no plans to road race on Hondas this year. He did not race at the North West 200 and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster and felt like a test rider. He believes the bike is not competitive for the Ulster Grand Prix and the team withdrew him from the event. Martin wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 governorship posts, while the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) won 8. This is the biggest defeat for the PDP since 1999, and follows their loss in the presidential poll last month. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State. The APC gained historic wins, especially in the north and Lagos, but did not win any oil-producing states. Elections were marred by violence in some areas, and the APC retained power in Lagos state. The PDP, in power for 16 years, is seen to be in decline due to voter desire for change, defections, corruption allegations, and failure to end the insurgency in the north-east.

Mighty, a US environmental group, has made claims against the agricultural commodities trader Olam, and its main stakeholder Temasek, accusing them of unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to haze. Both companies reject these allegations. Mighty's report suggests Olam and Temasek could be encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices and that Olam created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies". Olam's CEO states the firm has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and is vetting suppliers, and Temasek dismisses the allegations, supporting no-burn policies.
