A transport councillor stated it is a prototype with teething problems, and that electrical problems and groundings have been resolved, and ramp extensions are being made for vehicle scraping issues.

The UK fishing industry, which largely supported leaving the EU due to dissatisfaction with the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), sees Brexit as an opportunity to regain control of UK waters. However, a House of Lords report highlights potential risks, noting that while the industry is small economically, it should not be overlooked in Brexit negotiations.  Continued access to EU markets is crucial for the UK fishing industry, as most UK fish are exported to the EU, and the UK imports fish from the EU. This market access may require the UK to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters.  Despite potential challenges like managing shared fish stocks and the possibility of different fisheries management regimes within the UK, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit presents, as evidenced by recent EU quota agreements seen as beneficial for the UK. The government aims for maximum trade freedom with the EU while reviewing fisheries management post-Brexit.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014.  He received a community payback order and was placed on the sex offenders register earlier this year.  Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching register.  The images were primarily of young boys in erotic poses without sexual activity.  The hearing determined his conduct was incompatible with being a teacher, demonstrated a pattern of behaviour, and concluded there was a high chance of re-offending. He is prohibited from re-registering for two years.

A fire at a site in Duncan Street on 2 March, which disrupted train services, led the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. Despite the fire service stating the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA decided to revoke the environmental permit for the site, run by Asset and Land Group. Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited has until 7 August to appeal this decision, after which they will no longer be able to operate from the site and must remove all waste. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is trying its best to meet the deadline to destroy its chemical weapons, although Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mr Mekdad stated that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice by terrorist groups on its way to the port of Latakia.  Mr Mekdad described US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of barrel bombs as "absolutely unacceptable".  The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days by barrel bombs, while Syria insists they have never bombarded civilians and accuses the US of supporting terrorists.  Conflicting reports exist regarding Aleppo's central prison, with state media denying rebel seizure and the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights stating rebels freed hundreds of detainees.  Only 4% of Syria's 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons stockpile has left the country, causing concern from the US. Russia stated Syria should transfer weapons to the coast by 1 March, while the overall destruction deadline is the end of June. The OPCW acknowledged security concerns are slowing the process, but Mr Mekdad stressed Syria's commitment to its agreements.

England defeated Pakistan at Old Trafford to level the series. This victory is England's second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his performance, including a score of 254 in the first innings.  England's captain and coach praised Root's performance. Pakistan's batting was weak, and their captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment and cited shot selection and lack of confidence as reasons for their poor performance.  Geoffrey Boycott believes England will win the series, while Vaughan thinks the series will be tight.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review to hear about experiences of residential care from pensioners, their families and friends. This evidence will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales.  She aims to highlight good care and the impact of poor care. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment, involving input from care providers, social care staff and public bodies. The goal is to ensure services understand the realities of residential care and implement changes to improve the quality of life for older people. Mario Kreft from Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but is disappointed by the absence of a provider expert on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder and player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, is replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, according to chief executive Duncan Fraser. Sheerin, who has played for various Scottish clubs and Ãstersunds in Sweden and won a Scotland Under-21 cap, previously guided Arbroath to the Scottish Third Division title in 2011.

Following Bob Bradley's dismissal, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match. Swansea aims to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as their primary choice, to help them avoid relegation from the Premier League.  The club acknowledges the difficulty of returning to the Premier League if relegated, despite past successes. Swansea, promoted in 2011, was known for its exciting football and strong management, a stark contrast to their near bankruptcy in 2003. Curtis believes Swansea has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, citing frequent managerial changes and potentially inadequate player replacements. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad can avoid relegation and ensures new players are aware of the club's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his controversial approach to mapping the human genome, which was seen as a competitive race. He is described as immodest but his work undeniably sped up human genomics.  He created a synthetic life form called Synthia.  His early life included poor scholarship and surfing before his Vietnam War experience inspired him to become a doctor and value time, leading him to excel in gene research. He established private research institutes and companies after public funding issues, allowing him to pursue his scientific goals, including sequencing the first complete genome of a free-living organism and ocean microbe research. He believes synthetic microbes have the potential to start a new industrial revolution and help the environment.

This passage discusses concerns raised by the Sutton Trust regarding the quality and quantity of apprenticeships in England compared to other European countries, particularly Germany. The Sutton Trust report highlights that many apprenticeships are low level, short, and aimed at older workers, with low participation from employers and a complex qualification system.  The report recommends a radical expansion of high-quality, longer apprenticeships, primarily at level three and above, to improve job prospects for young people and boost the economy. While the Association of Colleges agrees on the need for quality and acknowledges the challenges of expansion, the Department for Education states they are already reforming apprenticeships to drive up standards.

Briton Storey won a cycling race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. Storey, who is aiming for her 17th title in Saturday's road race and Paralympic success in Rio, expressed relief at her win.  Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, she has won 21 world titles across cycling and swimming. Storey, aged 37, previously won six medals in swimming at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United have been expelled from the Conference Premier due to financial issues and failure to meet deadlines to pay football creditors, despite multiple deadline extensions. Chester has been reinstated to the Conference Premier as a result.  Hereford's financial problems have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with debts of Â£148,000 owed to football creditors and total debts around Â£225,000.  Tommy Agombar took over the club recently, but could not resolve the financial issues in time.  The club's financial situation worsened due to falling attendance figures.  Fans and the Supporters' Trust made efforts to save the club, but were unsuccessful.  This expulsion follows a dramatic final day of the season where Hereford stayed up, but ultimately their efforts were in vain.

James Milner, aged 30 and formerly of Manchester City, played 61 times for England's national team after his first appearance in 2009. He was part of the squads for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played for three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most caps for England's Under-21 team with 46, debuting in 2004. His single international goal was scored in a match against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after an illness lasting several months. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service at a later date. He was an influential figure in early music and founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for about 30 years. The AAM made over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a famous 1980 version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood held positions at the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, Early Music Consort of London, King's Lynn Festival, Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, Harvard University, University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. He was described as a great ambassador for historically informed music and a generous person by colleagues.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place at a special school, but in September were informed that special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full.  His mother stated he misses being around people and feels isolated.  The family has been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and they hope he can start there soon.  The mother is concerned about the special needs school system being at capacity and the Education Authority stated they are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure places are available, with work ongoing to assist with placements from 2016.

Newport Gwent Dragons are the subject of a takeover bid from the Welsh Rugby Union, who want to use Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League and expect their contract to be honoured. Shareholders for Newport Rugby will vote on the takeover on May 9th. Newport County agreed a 10-year lease in 2013. The WRU are aware that Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, but the WRU intends to install an artificial surface which is against Football League rules. Newport County are trying to avoid relegation from League Two, which would be a massive blow.

The country was declared free of a virus that caused almost 4,000 deaths over 18 months. A person was interviewed about their experiences in a civil war and their work during the Ebola crisis. During the civil war, they were kidnapped at 15 by rebels, forced to become a child soldier, and experienced violence and drug use. After escaping and being jailed, they met a preacher who inspired them to rebuild the nation. During the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, they developed a clinic, educated over 10,000 people about Ebola, provided food to 11,000 people, and set up an Ebola treatment unit. They witnessed a pregnant woman with suspected Ebola which motivated them to start the clinic with community help. They now focus on investing in young people. The passage also mentions that 3,955 people died from Ebola in Sierra Leone.

A public fundraising campaign successfully reached its target in a month to prevent 80,000 artworks from being auctioned to pay off pension debt of the pottery firm. The collection, which includes art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs, will remain at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund, who led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum before it is loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum. The collection was at risk of being sold after the Wedgwood Museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill and went into administration.

A deal is in progress where Mark Wright could buy 20% of Billericay Football Club and potentially become a club director. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off position. Mark Wright was runner-up in I'm A Celebrity in 2011 and has played non-league football. Billericay were recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin who is investing Â£10,000 a week and the club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool scored first with a goal by Jamille Matt in the first half, which was then equalised by Colchester's Kurtis Guthrie also in the first half. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made important saves during the match. Colchester ended the game with 10 players after Sean Murray received a red card.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is planned to be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard and the centrepiece of a "merchant city" development.  The power station closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation.  Architects plans show a petal-shaped glass structure at the centre of a ÃÂ£1bn development featuring a marina, housing and restaurants. It also includes fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could start in 2018. The oil-fired Fawley Power Station was commissioned in 1971 and was capable of powering one million homes.

Great Britain earned their second medal at the Hong Kong championships with a bronze medal won by 23-year-old Latham, following Elinor Barker's silver medal. Latham finished behind Teklinski of Poland who won gold, and Liss of Germany who won silver.  In other events, the GB men's team pursuit was beaten to bronze by Italy, Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the GB women's team pursuit finished fifth. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but is scheduled to compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, is returning to EastEnders for a brief period for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara's character, Peggy Mitchell, will be killed off due to cancer. Peggy Mitchell returned to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned. Grant Mitchell is returning to bring the Mitchell family together and say goodbye to his mother. Grant Mitchell was in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006.

Spurs were defeated at Anfield after Sadio Mane scored two goals.  Spurs manager Pochettino expressed disappointment in his team's performance, citing a lack of desire and stating it is difficult to contend for the Premier League title with such performances.  Pochettino also mentioned that Chelsea could extend their lead, creating a significant problem for Spurs. Spurs' away form is poor, with few wins against top-six sides. Danny Murphy criticised Spurs' defence and suggested they should have used a back three formation.  Spurs' away performances are in stark contrast to their home form and need immediate improvement.

Following Saturday's elections, the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the Peoples Democratic Party's (PDP) biggest defeat since 1999 and following their loss in the presidential poll last month. The PDP lost key northern states for the first time, but held onto Rivers State. They won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's gains are historic, making the PDP a regional party, although the APC did not win any oil-producing states, which is a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. Elections were marred by violence in some areas, but were generally more peaceful than in previous years. The APC also retained power in Lagos state, meaning the president's party will control Lagos for the first time since 1999. The PDP, in power for 16 years, is expected to introspect and rebuild after these losses, which were attributed to voter desire for change, defections, corruption allegations, and failure to end the insurgency in the north-east.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival can use an app to access online information from signs and posters. Online material includes videos and band interviews. The festival is in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The app is a new augmented reality experience to enhance enjoyment and allow people worldwide to interact with the festival. The app will be updated with information, interviews and tickets.

Academies Park View and Nansen Primary in Birmingham, both rated as inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding if concerns were not addressed. Saltley School, another inadequate school, will have a temporary governing board installed. These actions follow reports into schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover, with concerns including inadequate safeguarding and a narrow, faith-based ideology. A head teacher at one of the schools described feeling undermined by parents. Park View will challenge the Ofsted report, Saltley School aims to improve its rating, and parents have criticized Ofsted's reports as biased.

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after an eye test at Boots. Eye specialist Honey Rose is being prosecuted for gross negligence manslaughter because she allegedly failed to detect swollen optic discs during Vinnie's routine eye test and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution argues this failure led to a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, increased pressure in his skull, and ultimately his death, which they say was preventable. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg arranged meetings between a woman and a man from an adult website and filmed them having sex. He sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister and was found guilty of coercing the woman into sexual activity and intercourse, and intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Weatherhogg was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court and the case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and was described as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland played Afghanistan in a T20 match in Greater Noida, where they scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson scoring 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield adding 39 runs. Afghanistan chased this score, reaching 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47.  Afghan bowler Amir Hamza took 2 wickets. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. Ireland's captain, William Porterfield, mentioned they fell short of a bigger score and did not execute well with the ball.  Boyd Rankin missed the T20s due to a back problem but is expected to return for the ODIs starting on 15 March. The second T20 match will be at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona insists they committed no offence when signing Neymar for Â£48.6m, although his total cost is about Â£106.8m.  The transfer deal is under investigation, which led to Sandro Rosell resigning as president due to misappropriation allegations.  Despite denying tax-related crimes, Barcelona made a tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to protect their reputation. It is not confirmed if this payment will end the investigation.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were discovered dead on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK police assisted Thai authorities in the investigation into their murders, which led to the arrest of two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings. Thai police deny reports that the suspects withdrew their confessions. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery and could face the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office raised concerns about the investigation, specifically regarding DNA verification and mistreatment allegations. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a head blow, and Witheridge from head wounds. DNA found on Witheridge matched the suspects. UK police have completed their work in Thailand and will produce a report and update the families.

The Scottish team has won all five of their qualifiers and are playing Iceland at home. A win against Iceland would almost guarantee their place in the finals. Player Evans expresses the team's desperation to qualify after previous play-off losses. Iceland is ranked just above Scotland and is also unbeaten, making the upcoming games crucial for determining the group winner.  Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically for the finals in the Netherlands. Evans believes playing in top leagues abroad benefits the Scottish national team.

A security measure has been implemented by Apple to prevent third-party software from accessing iCloud and stealing user data, following the theft of celebrity photos. This measure is a two-step verification process for accessing iCloud backups, requiring a code in addition to a password when logging in from a new device.  If the code is not entered, access is denied, but a recovery key can be used if the trusted device is lost.  Previously, two-step verification was not applied to backups, leaving a vulnerability that software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker exploited.  Elcomsoft has acknowledged that Apple's new measure is effective.  Users now receive email notifications when a backup download starts.  Concerns remain about the recovery key's potential for loss or theft.  Experts suggest two-factor authentication should be the default setting, and Apple plans to encourage its use more aggressively.

For the election campaign between January 23rd and May 22nd, UKIP, the election winner, spent Â£2,956,737, and the Conservatives spent Â£2,980,815. Labour, who came second, spent Â£1,027,339, while the Liberal Democrats spent Â£1,580,575 and lost most of their MEPs.  Spending per vote ranged from 26p for Labour to Â£1.45 for the Liberal Democrats, with UKIP spending 68p and the Conservatives 79p per vote. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent Â£534,249, or 43p per vote.  The top six highest-spending parties, including the SNP at Â£267,372, spent a total of Â£9,347,087. All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join a rival National League team. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has joined the Gulls, recommended by Micky Adams. Anderson is described as a leader, while Keating is young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.

Following his win at the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, the 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed and died despite veterinary treatment. The British Horseracing Authority stated the horse suffered a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage", a rare event even in healthy horses.  Although the horse had previously shown signs of overheating after races, he displayed no such symptoms on Saturday, and the report concludes his death was due to the haemorrhage, not an underlying health issue.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to parliament. Ms. Marwick, Mr. Salmond, and Mr. McNeil are standing down as MSPs before the election on May 5th. In his speech, Mr. Salmond stated Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament needs greater responsibility. He welcomed the transfer of powers but felt the Scotland Bill did not fulfill referendum pledges. Mr. McNeil warned Holyrood should learn from Westminster regarding its committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie also gave a farewell speech, joking about missing interactions with John Swinney.

A film starring Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and will begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service will reveal their intentions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which ninety-six football fans died, at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST.  New inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed and files of evidence relating to twenty-three suspects were referred to the CPS. Fifteen suspects relate to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster and eight relate to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct after the disaster. Relatives will be informed of the decisions at a private meeting in Warrington by Sue Hemming from the CPS.  Victims' relatives are waiting for these decisions and want accountability.

Packages have been frequently thrown over the wall of Chelmsford Prison, according to prison residents.  A former inmate stated the prison is known for having issues with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges that staff are working to prevent contraband from entering prisons, but more needs to be done. A resident who lives nearby has witnessed packages being thrown over the wall multiple times recently. The prison is holding an event for residents to discuss how to handle packages being thrown over the wall.  A former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, but the Ministry of Justice stated there is no evidence of drone use at Chelmsford.  There are new laws in place that could jail people for up to two years for smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Brian Wright, 55, hit Mrs Blackburn with his VW Golf, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun, but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. Mr Wright expressed remorse in court, stating he understood Mrs Blackburn was a much-loved lollipop lady. The incident occurred when Mrs Blackburn, a lollipop lady of 20 years, was escorting a woman and child across the road at a red light, which Mr Wright's car failed to stop at. The trial is ongoing.

Muir told BBC Scotland that her veterinary medicine studies will prevent her from participating in next year's event in Australia. Muir finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Her exams in May clash with the Commonwealth Games in April. Muir is disappointed to miss the Commonwealth Games but is prioritising her degree. She is considering the World Indoor Championships in March. At the World Athletics Championships, Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m.

Trevor Deely, aged 22, disappeared in December 2000 after a Christmas party. A search is currently underway in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations expected to last weeks. This follows a review of his disappearance and enhancement of CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows Mr. Deely talking to a man in black, who police are trying to identify and are appealing for him to come forward.

Del Potro, ranked 165th, won against a Swiss player, despite being unranked for two years due to injury.  Del Potro will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Kyrgios also won his match against Dustin Brown and will play Feliciano Lopez next. Other players who won their matches include Berdych and Tsonga.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf during this year's Nations Cup, but they apologised to Caf. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup but the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned this ban. Morocco was previously punished for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola concerns, and the fine imposed on Morocco's FA was reduced by Cas. Tunisia's issues arose from a contentious penalty decision in a match against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 Nations Cup, leading to a formal complaint, though Tunisia denied accusing Caf of corruption.  After apologising and meeting with Caf, Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was confirmed. Both Tunisia and Morocco are participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw.

McLaren, a team with a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently aiming for a fourth or third row grid position, a significant fall from their past achievements.  Their slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and while they have improved the car, current problems are attributed to the Honda power-unit, contrasting with their past successes with Honda, particularly in the late 1980s and early 1990s with drivers like Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost.  McLaren's history is marked by cycles of success and decline, including periods of dominance and dips in performance, scandals, and changes in leadership, particularly with Ron Dennis. Despite current struggles, Dennis believes McLaren will overcome Mercedes' dominance and achieve future championships, a belief shared by Fernando Alonso who returned to the team with the hope of winning another title.  Currently, the team expresses belief in their progress and future success, despite lacking tangible results.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. Police found people still at the bar and receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and were fined Â£3,000 and Â£1,000 respectively. The judge highlighted that Ms O'Neill, the license holder, had "an appalling record".

Stephen Curry of the Golden State Warriors broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season in a game against the Portland Trail Blazers, achieving a 116-105 victory. Curry scored 45 points, including eight 3-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points for Golden State. In another game, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit, with Pau Gasol scoring 16 points and securing 15 rebounds for the Bulls.

Youtube star bas van velzen visited liverpool players mario balotelli , fabio borini , rickie lambert and lazar markovic at melwood . the liverpool players were under the impression van velzen was a competition winner who was there to receive a dead-ball masterclass , but van velzen showcased his free-kick skills and surprised the players . van velzen is a youtube sensation because of his free-kick videos and he enjoyed meeting the liverpool players and surprising them .

Women carrying the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed, a procedure called oophorectomy. A study showed that this procedure reduces the risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60% for BRCA1 mutation carriers. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with mutated genes and found a 62% reduction in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers who had an oophorectomy, but not for BRCA2 carriers.  For BRCA1 carriers who had the procedure within two years of diagnosis, the reduction in death was 73%.  Experts suggest oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment discussions for BRCA1 mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer, as it provides a survival benefit, especially for those with oestrogen-receptor negative breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed in Durham, North Carolina after being hit by an Amtrak train on Easter morning. The incident occurred shortly before 10 am on Sunday when train no. 80, the Carolinian, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, struck them on tracks owned by norfolk-southern.  None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, though one man received treatment for illness during the delay. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its route. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp.

This passage describes Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former member of the Medellin cartel who worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of US citizenship.  Despite his service as a strong asset in undercover stings and aiding in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, he is now facing deportation as he did not receive citizenship.  Retired due to declining health, Toro is living in the US illegally and fears for his life if deported to Colombia, as the DEA has refused to assist him with citizenship.

This passage discusses the '.sucks' domain name and the company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. that is using it to charge high prices to celebrities and companies to protect their reputations.  The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal after complaints from an advisory panel.  Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift, and companies such as Youtube, Bing, and Visa have been targeted and some have paid to remove their names from '.sucks' domains.  Vox Populi is charging around $2,499 a year for these domains, although they will be offered to the public for $10 a year later.

A baby boy was found deceased in a Sainsbury's bag in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk in 1988.  After 27 years and a case review, the baby's body was exhumed, and DNA samples identified his mother.  The mother was arrested but explained the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy.  Police have ruled out foul play, but the mother remains on bail and may be charged with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby has been reburied and named Peter.

A taxi driver has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger who sustained severe brain injuries after jumping from the moving car. The driver, Michael Young, mistakenly believed the passenger, Kristopher Hicks, was going to avoid paying the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank.  As a result, Mr Hicks jumped from the taxi while it was travelling at over 20mph and suffered brain injuries. The High Court ruled that Mr Young had unlawfully imprisoned Mr Hicks and that Mr Hicks is entitled to damages, the exact amount of which is still to be decided. Mr Hicks now requires round-the-clock care due to his injuries.

Tornado sirens were activated in Kansas on Wednesday night due to storms that brought reports of twisters. A tornado was reported near Goddard, Kansas, moving northeast and posing risks to communities outside of Wichita.  There were other tornado reports from southwestern Kansas, specifically near Aetna.  Missouri was also affected, with a possible tornado in Potosi and reports of wind damage and flooding.  Large hail was reported in Farmington. More storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are scheduled to fight in a middleweight match in New Jersey on Saturday. Rockhold is aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot, planning to dominate Machida by being aggressive and exploiting perceived weaknesses in Machida's fighting style. Rockhold is confident in his diverse fighting skills and superior speed and stamina. Machida is also aiming for a title shot and is confident he can win by applying his own fighting style and technique and finding weaknesses in Rockhold. Both fighters are coming off recent victories and believe the winner of their fight should be considered for a title shot.

A light general aviation aircraft, identified as an Aerostar plane, landed without its landing gear deployed at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The aircraft skidded on its belly along the runway, and its propellers hit the ground. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, aged 85, then re-engaged the engines and took off again. Despite the damage, the pilot managed to fly approximately 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The video maker of the incident suggested the pilot's mistake was forgetting to deploy the landing gear, which is a common cause of such landings, and the FAA is investigating the incident. The pilot was accompanied by his dog, Buddy.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment with Yaya Toure's performance this season but will support him until the end of the season. Manchester City may consider offers for Toure in the summer as they plan to overhaul their ageing squad.  Despite criticism and underperformance, Toure does not want to leave.  Joe Hart stated that the players take responsibility for poor performances and that the team supports Pellegrini. Manchester City is interested in signing Aaron Cresswell from West Ham, but Sam Allardyce has warned Cresswell against making this move.

Domenico Rancadore, known as the 'godfather of Uxbridge' and a Sicilian mafia fugitive, will be allowed to remain in the UK. He was initially set to be extradited to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence given in 1999 for mafia association. However, his sentence expired in October of last year because Italian law states sentences expire after a period of more than double the penalty time has passed.  Although his conviction remains, the Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish the sentence, and his European arrest warrant is being withdrawn.  This outcome follows a lengthy extradition battle and some administrative errors by the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), which caused delays in the proceedings.  While the Italian Supreme Court still needs to hear the case, Rancadore's solicitor is confident he will be discharged and able to live peacefully in England.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is a 7-2 co-favourite in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday.  This race will be McCoy's last ride in a grade one race.  Mr Mole is trained by Paul Nicholls and will compete against six rivals including Special Tiara, Sprinter Sacre ridden by Nico de Boinville, and Somersby.  McCoy's decision to retire was announced after riding Mr Mole to victory in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia, who was murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body after 40 years. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett.  Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and despite advice against it from her then-husband, Ritter viewed the photos last year. The photos depicted Marcia's body with injuries and caused Ritter to express a desire for revenge. Jerome Sydney Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years. Barrett was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to Marcia's murder, which was Nashville's most notorious unsolved case for 33 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam. He considers his final-round collapse at Augusta in 2011 as the most important day of his career. McIlroy is aiming to be the sixth player to win all four major titles and believes winning every major would make him a complete player. He has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and hopes to complete his grand slam at Augusta. McIlroy reflects on his 2011 Masters experience as a significant learning opportunity that helped him win his first major title later that year. He sees the golf course as his sanctuary from pressure and hype.

This week's trending stories include rainbows in New York, China banning exotic dancers at wakes, and RDJ's agitated interview.  The #kyliejennerchallenge lip plumping trend, 102-year-old Alice Barker's film project, and a rejected bomb prom-posal with racism accusations also trended.  Additionally, Ewan McGregor's Beauty and the Beast casting, Johnny Depp's Black Mass trailer, a Fresh Prince pregnancy announcement, and a military dad photobomb were trending stories.

In the past year, 272 children were hospitalised in England with brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome, according to official data. Experts warn the actual number is likely higher. Research suggests at least one in 100 babies in the UK may have problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to about 7,500 yearly.  Foetal alcohol syndrome is a significant and under-diagnosed issue, and children do not recover from it.  One example is Niamh Brown, a 15-year-old with foetal alcohol syndrome who requires constant care.  Alcohol consumption during pregnancy can also lead to other medical issues like liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy.  Current government advice for pregnant women is to avoid alcohol, or if they drink, to limit consumption to two units twice a week, but some believe the guidance should be abstinence.

Axe-wielding Shaun Andrew McKerry attempted to rob Shildon post office and stores at 8 pm on March 15.  Shopkeeper Sab Dhillon tackled McKerry, and his wife Sam hit McKerry with a baseball bat, disarming him. Police arrived and arrested McKerry who was later jailed for six years for attempted robbery. McKerry was known as 'boomerang boy' or 'homing pigeon boy' due to his history of returning home after committing crimes, starting from age 12 and accumulating 80 arrests by age 15.

Four royal navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party at a canadian barracks in nova scotia and must remain there until trial. The sailors appeared in court in dartmouth and were granted bail with conditions including surrendering passports and living at the stadacona naval base in halifax. The accused are joshua finbow, simon radford, craig stoner, and darren smalley. The alleged sexual assault occurred on april 10th after an ice hockey tournament at the shearwater naval base. The sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault and are ordered to return to court on may 27th.

RJ Jackson, a four-year-old, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare condition causing his skin to appear red and scaly.  His mother, Valerie Jackson, was reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook RJ's condition for signs of scalding. This incident occurred while shopping in Las Vegas and highlights the public's ignorance about Netherton's syndrome, which is a congenital skin disease with no cure.  RJ's condition also leads to bullying and social exclusion for him and his family.

The Protein World "are you beach body ready?" advertisement campaign, featuring a bikini-clad model, in the London Underground has been met with significant backlash. Campaigners, feminists, and the public found the posters offensive and promoting an unhealthy body image, leading to a petition with over 50,000 signatures and over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority. Transport for London is removing the posters as the paid advertising period has ended. While Protein World defends their campaign and has received threats, the Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints.

Rail firms planned fare hikes after the general election, despite party leaders promising to freeze prices. First Great Western planned to increase some fares by up to 87 per cent on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which prompted Prime Minister Cameron to request an urgent review of this decision.  Other rail firms like London Midlands and Virgin also planned fare increases. First Great Western stated the fare change was to align the north Cotswolds route with other services. Virgin said their price hikes mainly affected cheaper fares and their overall fare increase was low. Train companies can increase 'unregulated' fares, which are around half of their revenue.

Former soldier John Young, aged 66, was blinded in one eye after thugs threw bricks at his home in Oldham. This occurred around 11 pm last Friday, April 18th, while he and his wife Elaine were writing thank you cards three weeks after their wedding.  When Mr. Young opened his front door to confront the individuals throwing stones and bricks at his property, he was hit in the eye by a brick.  Police are investigating the incident, suggesting there is no known motive and it may be a case of 'yobs messing around'.  Mr. Young feels unsafe and is moving away from his home.

Tom Poynton, a Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension as a reward for successfully returning from injury. He missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident where his father died, and underwent an ankle operation. He made his comeback in Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and work ethic and hopes the contract gives him confidence.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer called neuroblastoma, which affected his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones. He used a ninja turtle mask during radiotherapy to feel stronger and decorated his protective mask, which amazed hospital staff. After undergoing chemotherapy, an operation, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, Harley has been declared cancer-free. His story gained media attention, and he received gifts from Nickelodeon. Neuroblastoma is a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year and is cancer of specialised nerve cells. Harley's family is overjoyed at his recovery, and he will have regular check-ups.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should concentrate on his Aston Villa career rather than his international future. Sherwood is impressed with Grealish, who played well in Aston Villa's FA Cup semi-final win against Liverpool. Grealish is wanted by both the Republic of Ireland and England for international play, but Sherwood wants Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career first. Sherwood states it is up to Grealish to decide his international future, and Grealish's father agrees that his son must concentrate on his club football first. Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:
Landing fees for private jets can vary significantly at different airports, with some surprising locations having the highest charges, indicating popular hubs for wealthy travellers. Private jet travel is a growing industry worth trillions of dollars, with peak demand during major sporting events like the Super Bowl. Japan has the most expensive landing fees, with Haneda airport being the highest.  A list of airports with high landing fees is provided, including locations such as Dublin, Bristol, LaGuardia, and Salzburg.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon took her dog Cooper and her other dog Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. Cooper ate his ice cream cone in one bite, while Daisy licked hers slowly. Katie Gallegos runs a dog resort and says Cooper always eats quickly. The video of Cooper eating ice cream has been watched more than seven million times. Some people criticized Katie for giving her dogs ice cream, but she says it is fine. Cooper and Daisy also get 'pup-uccinos' from Starbucks.

Gary Locke has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock after signing a three-year deal. He was previously the interim manager, taking over in February when Allan Johnston quit.  Before becoming interim manager, Locke was assistant boss to Johnston since last summer.  As interim manager, Locke lost only one game out of seven.

A mother in Florida reported that Seminole County Elementary threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for wearing essential oils, manufactured by doterra, to help him stay calm and focused. The school considered the oils to be smelly and a distraction. The mother argued that the oils are natural and questioned why they are not acceptable when chemicals are.  However, the Lake County School District stated they would not suspend the son, referring to it as a 'health issue'. The family uses doterra oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A fire obliterated a beach-side apartment complex with 90 condos in Westhampton beach on Wednesday at 3 pm. Smoke poured over the area and was visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews responded but could not get inside the building due to the intensity of the flames, which melted paint off nearby buildings. The cause of the fire is unknown but is being investigated, with claims it started near a car. The complex, named Sandpiper, is used as holiday homes and is open between May and November. The building manager, who lived and worked there, stated he has lost everything.

The Queen, aged 88 and approaching 89, was seen riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park.  She prefers silk scarves to helmets while riding.  The Queen has loved horses since she was four and has owned many horses throughout her life, including Betsy and Surprise.  She breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court and Highland ponies at Balmoral.  Although she has reduced riding due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic rider and her grandchildren ride her ponies. Fell ponies, like Carltonlima Emma, are an old breed from Cumbria, historically used for various purposes and are now popular riding horses.

A disagreement about noise between two neighbours in Brisbane resulted in the death of Leon Yeaman, aged 55. Phillip Pama, aged 28, has been charged with manslaughter for allegedly punching Mr. Yeaman in the head. The incident occurred at Mr. Yeaman's home on Muller Road around 9 pm on Thursday night, after Mr. Yeaman was making noise. Mr. Pama, a shift worker who was trying to sleep, confronted Mr. Yeaman. Mr. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 pm. Mr. Pama was granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, talks to god every day but not about football and does not discuss football with his wife. Mourinho and his family are aware of poverty and have worked with the world food programme. Mourinho separates his professional and family life and has a strong faith in god, praying every day and going to church when he feels the need, especially in Portugal. Mourinho prays for personal matters, not about Chelsea, and considers himself a good person despite his arrogant public persona. He acknowledges making mistakes in his competitive professional life but believes a person is more than their profession. Mourinho was fined earlier in the season for claiming a campaign against Chelsea. Mourinho prays daily and goes to church regularly in Portugal.

Bob Barker, a TV legend, returned to hosting "The Price is Right" for the first time in eight years on April 1.  Instead of Drew Carey, Bob Barker hosted the show, handling the "lucky seven" game. Barker hosted the show for 35 years before 2007.  Drew Carey then took over hosting duties. Barker appeared comfortable hosting despite his absence.

An off-duty secret service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. at 12:30 a.m. on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property by the Metropolitan Police on the 3200 block of D street se.  Following the arrest, the agency revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave from his position in the foreign missions branch. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned on Friday afternoon. This arrest follows another incident where a supervisor was put on leave for misconduct and adds to existing investigations into the agency.

A freelance photographer named Atif Saeed from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a hungry lion in a safari park in Lahore. Mr. Saeed got out of his car and approached within ten feet of the lion with only a camera. He lay on the ground to take pictures, aiming to capture the lion's character and status. The lion was alerted by the camera sound and jumped towards Mr. Saeed, who quickly retreated to his car. Mr. Saeed described it as a close encounter and now doubts he would repeat the action.

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn near shore parkway and 26th avenue.  She had a distinctive heart tattoo with the name 'Monique' on her right leg and no identification. The NYPD released an image of the tattoo to help identify her and are asking for information from the public. The cause of her death is currently unknown as police are awaiting a medical examiner's report.

This New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, constructed a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK because they could not afford to buy property. This year and a half project resulted in a solar-powered, wood and steel home in Nelson, New Zealand, enabling them to live almost self-sufficiently. The home is powered by solar panels, uses water from a nearby spring, and cost them $25,000.

Research suggests that kindergarten children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests compared to children who do not share or have their own devices. This is according to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University.  Children sharing iPads scored around 30 points higher than students who used devices individually or not at all.  The researcher suggests that collaborative learning around the technology is the key factor.

A piglet with missing back legs has become an internet sensation due to a video showing it learning to walk on its front trotters.  This piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', belongs to Ms. Duan from Qionglai city in Sichuan province, China.  Despite sometimes looking like it might fall, it always regains balance and lives with its four-legged siblings.  Villagers have visited to see this unusual animal, and it is noted that this is not the first two-legged animal in China to gain attention, as a rabbit in Liuzhou zoo also became popular for walking on its front paws.

A pit crew member was hit by a car during the Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. Todd Phillips, a tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box and hit Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center for a cut on his leg and released. The incident occurred on lap 25 when Dracone came in for tires and fuel. Dracone did not finish the race and finished in 23rd place. Many cars had traction issues due to rain before the race.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in the garden of their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.  CCTV footage shows Severiano smashing his wife's head into concrete paving 11 times and then shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the murder, stating jealousy of men looking at his wife as the reason.  A neighbour reported hearing an argument and Severiano yelling accusations at his wife before the incident.  After the murder, Severiano stole a car but was arrested after crashing it. Police found multiple weapons in the car. Severiano faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, the journalist and author of 'i quit sugar', revealed in an interview her personal battle with mental illness. She explained that anxiety led her to a point where she felt life was not worth continuing due to stress, anxiety, thyroid disease and distant family, making her feel isolated.  Although she struggled in younger years, she has recently found peace with it and now accepts she is an anxious person. Ms Wilson believes anxiety and depression are linked, and anxiety is becoming the 'new depression', noting that many Australian women are affected by stress and anxiety.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, was initially charged with second-degree assault for hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom.  The charge was dropped because prosecutors determined Curtin was justified in her outrage, as Oregon law permits the use of physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a residence.  Curtin was pregnant at the time of the incident and her defense attorney stated the ex-girlfriend had been harassing Curtin and trying to disrupt her relationship.  If convicted, Curtin could have faced a mandatory prison sentence.

This passage describes Gemma, a pit bull in California, being filmed at home while being fed treats.  Her owner attempted to trick her by including broccoli with the treats. Gemma reacted with disgust to the broccoli, chewing it and then spitting it onto the floor. Gemma lives with two children, and the passage expresses hope that they will not imitate her dislike of vegetables.  Other videos show Gemma also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC has apologised after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. This occurred because the link was for the 'young entrepreneur awards' page, which was shut down after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the domain registration retired.  As a result, a porn site took over the address. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website, denied any association with the external site, and apologised to the public for the inconvenience. HSBC stated that its website remained secure.

A 13-year-old boy in Maryland called 911 after a fire started in his home in Clinton on Sunday morning. The boy and his nine-year-old sister were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. The boy calmly provided instructions to the dispatcher during an 11-minute call and directed firefighters to their location. Firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window and entering the room. The siblings were taken to children's hospital with non-life threatening injuries. Three other family members escaped on their own and were taken to medstar hospital. Firefighter Lt Kenny Ward gave his gas mask to the little girl during the rescue.

Blue fluorescent algae has been seen lighting up australia 's east coast in jervis bay on the south coast of nsw. photographer andy hutchinson described the sight as a ` beautiful supernatural scene ' caused by millions of plankton omitting light. a similar display was seen in sydney 's manly beach in august 2014. iain suthers , of university of new south wales , says the algae is called noctiluca scintillans , a single celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn and the glow is a defence mechanism.

New tests can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumours to determine the risk of the disease returning after surgery, potentially allowing some patients to avoid chemotherapy and its side effects. These tests can tell women within days if they have a low risk, which for some is as low as five per cent, comparable to chemotherapy.  Experts suggest these tests should be available on the NHS due to potential cost savings and to help patients make informed choices, as illustrated by the case of Becca Cornford who avoided chemotherapy due to a low risk score from the endopredict test.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy.  HMS Ocean had five pregnant sailors removed over nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond had emergency evacuations.  A 'no touching' rule suggests women conceived before boarding ships or during leave.  Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan and 102 from Iraq after finding out they were pregnant. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was discovered on the roof of the Japanese equivalent of the White House. This discovery is raising concerns about potential drone terrorism, especially in relation to upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The drone was found on the same day a Japanese court approved restarting nuclear reactors, a move unpopular due to the Fukushima disaster. The drone contained a camera, smoke flares, and cesium, a byproduct of nuclear reactors also found at Fukushima. While the amount of cesium was not immediately harmful, the government is reviewing drone operations and terrorism threats.  There are currently no drone flight restrictions in Tokyo except near airports. The Prime Minister was not present at the residence when the drone was found.

A security guard from China takes his 84-year-old mother to work with him on his motorbike every day because she suffers from alzheimer's and he is scared she will get lost if left alone. He ties them together with a sash for safety during the journey to work, which is four kilometres and takes an hour. His mother has her own room at his workplace, a bank, where he checks on her. He feels it is his duty to care for her as she cared for him when he was young.

Americans are drinking heavily and binge drinking more, according to a major study of alcohol use. Heavy drinking in the U.S. increased by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, particularly among women. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men in the past month. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month.  Researchers found that changing social norms are driving the increase, especially for women. In 2012, 8 percent of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18 percent were binge drinkers.  This increase in drinking is linked to 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and an estimated cost of over $220 billion per year.  Possible reasons for the increase include changing social norms, cheaper alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study analyzed data from 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, which puts the health of women and babies at risk.  They state caesareans should only be carried out when medically necessary due to risks of infections and death.  In England, just over a quarter of births are caesarean, more than double the rate since the early 1990s, with some women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety. The World Health Organisation (WHO) suggests the ideal rate should be 10 to 15 per cent due to dangers and costs.  WHO states caesareans performed without medical need can cause short and long-term health problems, complications, disability or death, and divert funds.  Caesareans are more expensive than natural births.  WHO contradicts NHS guidelines which allow caesareans even without medical justification, including for women with tokophobia.  WHO believes doctors are performing caesareans too often and underestimating the risks, with research showing that one in ten caesareans cause infections.

A woman named Michelle Filkins was arrested for allegedly breaking into a home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard.  She is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property.  The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins at his property on April 17th.  Filkins had been living in the home for at least a week and selling items from the house in a yard sale.  Police are asking for the public to return any items they may have received from the home. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14th.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was handed to Albury police station. Police officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and photos on Bella's Facebook page to locate her. The posts included humorous captions and updates about the phone being safe at the police station. Bella, who lost her phone at a birthday party, retrieved it from the police station after seeing the Facebook posts and found the situation funny.  She was recognised by police from her Facebook page and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was mauled to death after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in isimangaliso wetland park, eastern south africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water as its mother watched in horror. The calf died hours after the incident. A tour operator named Stacey Farrell witnessed the event. The mother of the calf had stayed with her herd, believing it safer, but this decision proved fatal when the calf was caught by one of the fighting adults.

This three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London is on the market for Â£575,000. This is considered a bargain price for the area, but the property has a short lease of only three years remaining. The cost of the property for the duration of the lease is comparable to the monthly rental rate for a similar apartment in the area. Extending the lease could increase the property's value to upwards of Â£6 million. Estate agents have noted that properties with such short leases are rare in Knightsbridge and this property has generated significant interest.

A computer outage impacted Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, affecting 8,000 locations and disrupting sales.  Due to the register issues, Starbucks gave away free drinks and baked goods, and some stores closed early on Friday. The outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, was resolved, and stores were expected to open as usual on Saturday.  This event occurred after Starbucks announced record quarterly earnings.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural west wales, specifically in locations including ceredigion , powys and pembrokeshire. These locations are being used to radicalise muslims, according to an officer from the wales extremism and counter terrorism unit.  These individuals participate in ordinary activities but have ulterior motives.  Incidents of islamic extremist activity in wales can be traced back to 1998.  In 2005, two of the 7/7 bombers were photographed in north wales.  In 2010, three would-be terrorists from cardiff were arrested for plotting terror attacks.  Michael adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering fusilier lee rigby, is understood to have studied in wales.  Three would-be terrorists from cardiff held secret meetings in a country park in wales. Community intelligence is vital to authorities.

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, which was feared to be extinct, has been discovered on a west Australian beach. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The identification of the 5.68m juvenile female was initially difficult but was confirmed through DNA profiling.  This discovery is considered highly significant by the environment minister as very little is known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003 and is usually found in tropical and subtropical waters such as Indonesian waters, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan. The knowledge gained from this whale will help to improve understanding of the species. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried for future scientific investigation.

This passage discusses the idea that a female presidential candidate's hormones, specifically Hillary Clinton's, might make her irrational and prone to starting wars, as suggested by businesswoman Cheryl Rios.  The passage counters this by pointing out that male hormones have also historically led to poor decisions by male leaders and that studies suggest women leaders are less likely to take unnecessary risks.  It argues that the real issue is gender bias, which is a significant obstacle for women in leadership, including politics and the workplace. The passage emphasizes that gender bias is detrimental to society and that equality benefits everyone.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his antique collection at auction for Â£100,000 because he is downsizing his home. The collection of over 200 items includes furniture, paintings, books, military items like swords and flintlock rifles, and a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt. The auction is being held by Dominic Winter auctioneers in Gloucestershire this Saturday. Mr. Hardy, known for roles in 'All Creatures Great and Small' and for playing Winston Churchill, is selling the collection due to his interest in classic literature and military history.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida, and is currently on the run.  Police began investigating Shemansky after he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead in their shared home.  Foul play is suspected in Sandra Shemansky's death. Michael Scott Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness and a past suicide attempt.  Neighbors believe divorce proceedings and recent bad news may have triggered him, and that his mother may have prevented him from attending the visit with his son. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not released details about it or the cause of death. Shemansky fled on foot and authorities are asking for information on his whereabouts at 407-656-3636.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision by the International Association of Athletics Federations council bypassed the usual bidding process, citing a 'unique strategic opportunity' to host the championships for the first time in the USA. Eugene had previously bid for the 2019 event but lost to Doha. The IAAF president highlighted the strategic importance of this decision for accessing a key market and for the global development of the sport, noting that the 2007 World Championships in Osaka were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger targeted Hassan after seeing him with a large amount of cash at a London casino. She befriended him and then lured him to his flat where she allowed her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and Nicholas Chandler to enter. Jackson and Chandler tied up and fatally assaulted Hassan to steal his winnings. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy described the attack as 'pitiless and wicked'. Granger claimed she was influenced by Jackson and Chandler, but the judge stated she was deceitful and lost her compassion.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, is experiencing a decline in form during the second half of the season, a trend observed throughout his career, as noted by Barcelona.  His form has dipped since around Christmas, and he performed poorly in a game for Spain against Holland.  Despite this dip, Chelsea is likely to win the Premier League and has already won the Capital One Cup.  Fatigue from playing many minutes is suggested as a reason for his decline.  Although he started the season brilliantly and was on track to break the assist record, his assist numbers have significantly dropped in 2015.  Despite the slump, he has a good record against Chelsea's remaining opponents, and Mourinho hopes his recent assist against Hull City is a sign of resurgence as Fabregas is key to Chelsea winning the Premier League.

West Ham are in discussions to sign Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old forward who impressed on trial and has other offers.  West Ham also revealed Olympic Stadium season tickets will start at Â£289, the cheapest in the Premier League for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped an investigation into an assault on huntsman Mike Lane, who is 40 years old and joint master of the Tedworth Hunt. The assault occurred three months prior by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars.  Despite video evidence and a dossier of evidence given to Wiltshire police, they have stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence. The attack happened in Everleigh, near Amesbury, where protesters sprayed hounds with citronella and then assaulted Mr. Lane, causing injuries including concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss.  Hunt supporters and Mr. Lane are dismayed by the police decision, and the Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs. Wiltshire police state the case is undetected but could be reopened with new evidence.

Adam Gadahn, known as the "american mouthpiece of al qaeda", was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January.  He was not specifically targeted, nor was Ahmed Farouq, another U.S. al qaeda operative who died in a separate operation. Warren Weinstein, a U.S. hostage, died in the attack that killed Farouq. Gadahn was a prominent al qaeda member and propagandist. Born in 1978, he converted to Islam in 1995 and joined al qaeda in 1998. He became al qaeda's chief English propagandist after 9/11, appearing in videos threatening attacks and urging violence against American, Western, and Jewish targets. Indicted for treason and material support to al qaeda in 2006 and on the FBI's "most wanted terrorists" list, Gadahn criticized U.S. presidents, urged lone-wolf attacks, praised terrorist acts, and called for government overthrow. He played a key role in al qaeda's media strategy and was married with at least one child.

This passage describes a five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo who is a rising basketball superstar. A viral video showcases his impressive basketball skills, which include scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs, and has gained him many fans in China.  He has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old and his talent has stunned netizens.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of Hacked Off. PIE campaigned to legalise child sex in the 1970s and 80s. Hacked Off is a media pressure group campaigning for statutory press regulation, formed after the phone-hacking scandal. O'Carroll, a former activist for PIE, attended a Hacked Off rally to lobby for state involvement in media regulation. The news of O'Carroll's support is considered an embarrassment for Hacked Off.

The Bondi Icebergs pool was drained on Thursday for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. This was to create a catwalk for the 'ten pieces' presentation, a unisex collection of ten items designed to be worn in 20 ways. The show, showcasing monochrome and androgynous designs, took place in the empty pool and along the break wall, with guests watching from the balcony and passers-by observing from public areas. The 'ten pieces' brand is headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and his partner Lucy Hinckfuss. Guests at the show enjoyed food and drinks in sunny and warm weather.

Amir Khan, a boxer, spent a Friday at a safari park in northern california with his wife faryal makhdoom khan and daughter lamysa.  During the visit to six flags discovery kingdom he posed with giraffes and sea lions and fed a white tiger.  Khan announced his next fight will be against chris algieri at welterweight on may 30.

A Palestinian teenager named Mohammed Abu Khdeir had his name added to an Israeli memorial for fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. This was objected to by his family and an organization called Almagor, who stated he was not a victim of terror and should not be listed with soldiers.  Following complaints, the teenager's name will be removed from the memorial.

A young boy in California, the son of youtube user lionel hutz, attempts to use his family cat as a pillow in the garden. The cat, initially licking its fur, is then laid upon by the boy. The cat moves away, and the boy follows and repeats this action multiple times until the cat goes inside.  A later video shows the boy and cat are friendly again with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial is occurring in Philadelphia.  Robert Kushner, a witness in the trial, lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about selling marijuana in the past. Kushner is one of multiple former drug dealers testifying for the government regarding police wrongdoing allegations.  Kushner testified that police officers on trial stole money and marijuana from him in 2007. Lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering state that the government's case is based on lying drug dealers.

A chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, experienced an explosion and fire, injuring six people. The plant produces paraxylene (PX). The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak. Five of the six injuries were caused by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters brought the fire under control. Residents nearby heard the explosion and shared photos online. This plant had a previous explosion in July 2013 and PX plants are known to be controversial in China. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated due to pollution concerns in 2007.

Jack Grealish will not pull his socks up despite being asked to by referees. This is due to superstition. He wears his socks low and wears children's shinpads. He made his first premier league start for Aston Villa against QPR. He was pleased to have made his first start.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has irreversible brain damage according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston.  Although no longer in a coma, she is unresponsive.
